Posted: November 25, 2013
												I think Magicka is probably the best mage-game out there. With its amazing sense of satirical humor, Magicka really does bring out out the laughs very often. The game also has an amazing blend of gameplay, music (which I must say is very good for most Paradox games), and graphics, which really is great for the environment, but especially for the Magicks. I think the only con for this game is the optimization, which makes the game run dreadfully on potatoes. And majorly, the bugs, probably the biggest downside to this game, makes some areas almost unplayable. However, the support from Paradox is very good and really puts the game up-the scale.

Posted: June 10, 2014
												When you start Magicka you don't know what you're up to. Cast your first spell, destroy something, kill yourself, burn down a house, melt cheese or just grill some sausages. This big adventure will require skills to learn to cast spells as fast as you can. This is only way to survive sometimes. On top of that you'd rather be smart to find the weak points of many different foes who will come across your journey. Having  troubles passing through an area? Just call some friends and they will help you in a fight or just cast the wrong spell on you :p. Well Magicka is a unique game without vampires ;-).I recommend that you also read the e-book : The Ninth Element. It is well written and fully in sync with the humour of the game.Some DLCs will give you a very hard time to defeat the bosses but that's where you should call your friends for online adventure.

number of helpful: 137 of 144 people (95%) found this review helpful15 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												At first glance Magicka will look like a fun button mashing experience to have with your friends. If you look further you will see that there is more enjoyment to experience from Magicka than you could ever see from the trailers and screenshots. Magicka has created something that no game had ever done before (at least not well). From just a combination of buttons you can create powerful spells that bare strategy behind them. Of course there are a number of downsides and bugs to this game that when overlooked barely interfere with the gameplay at all and will usually result in a laugh. Make no mistakes, this game is for pure fun and joy.If you are looking for a game to play with your friends then look no further because this game is precisely what you need. You are getting a lot more fun out of this game than the price would intend you to believe. At such a low price you get hours of gameplay excluding all of the tremendous amount of downloadable content. Magicka is a co-op game that brings out the evil inside you and your friends. You can be on your way to defeating the infamous Grimnir when out beaming behind you is a beam of arcane from your companion aiming directly for you. Magicka really brings out the troll in most people and with countless of opportunities to kill you your friends will never get bored killing you and reviving you, killing and reviving you, killing and... yeah.For the serious competitors that don't like the limitations that Magicka: Wizard Wars gives you but are still interested in the humor and game mechanics of Magicka then the pvp or challenge modes will prove to be very effective gamemodes. As stated before Magicka has a very diverse field of strategy. For example someone will be coming at you with some fire so you have to quickly decide to cast a fire shield onto yourself to become immune to fire and then come at them with the most unexpected attacks in order to win a player versus player match. Challenge mode also includes some strategy and competition. Once you die in challenge you're done for and must start from square one. This means you can compete against your friends and see who is the greater wizard.Now I bring you the bugs, glitches and problems this game faces. The bugs in this game are usually hilarious to see happen to someone you are playing with and usually funny to watch when they happen to you. These are the small bugs that don't affect you in a huge way when playing Magicka but through your playthrough it is not unlikely to come across a big glitch that will require you to restart the game and have you go back to the last checkpoint. Another thing that could be considered a problem in this game is it's massive amount of downloadable content which could possibly be a deal breaker for you if you just hate paying just a bit extra for a full package. What I must reassure you with is the fact that none of the extra content is required to feel whole although it is a bit depressing when you look at your robes and see a horde of robes unable to play with. When it comes to actual level and gameplay dlc Paradox have done something I must praise them for. When playing online only the host needs the downloadable content in order to play it so essentially you could play every dlc level without ever paying a cent.This was the first game I had in my library and it's what got me interested in steam. So as someone who has had their lives changed (or ruined from the access to almost every modern pc game developed) I say buy this game whenever you get the chance. If you're interested in humour, magick, wizards, co-op, being a troll, strategic moves, unstrategic fails, using powerful combos that wipes everything off the screen causing you all to go back to the start of the game, competition or vampires that think no one knows that they are vampires then I highly recommend to try this game out regardless if you're a loner and can't find anyone to play it with.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2013
												Updated Review.One of the most fun spellcasting systems I have ever seen! Knowing what to cast in what situation has never been more satisfying. The concept itself of combining elements to make spells had me sold, and the game itself managed to value that potential. The freedom of doing whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you want whenever you want is amazing. No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t mana bars. No crappy skill trees. No cooldowns. Pure, unaltered, raw power, scaled with your skill level. Some DBZ style♥♥♥♥♥♥here.There are downsides though:- arrowhead did one of the crappiest netcodes in existence. Crashes happen. Connections don't. Hosting doesn't work most of the time. Multiplayer is such an amazing experience, be it Adventure, Challenge or Versus and crap like this stands in the way. If you can overlook that, this game is easily a 88/100, but with the crappy 1998 multiplayer, the score is rightfully dragged down to 74.- latency in this game is on steroids for some reasons, probably bad optimization- too few people play, and because of the crappy matchmaking system you need to know people's numbers and have friends that play- they pump out a ton of DLCs, something that I hate on principle- the devs aren't really fixing much. They're adding more stuff and grabbing lodsemoneh- limited to a max of 4 players per game (and I think having way more would've been so much fun; game is not made for this)The PROS:- the combinations you can do with those 8 elements is mindblowing- so much fun in all 3 modes: Adventure, Challenge and especially Versus if you are at a high skill level and monsters are too weak- skill level can be INSANE. One guy can take out 100 other wizards and 1000 mobs, without getting a scratch.- single player is a lot of fun: comedic story, fun missions, DLCs aren't bad, they're just short- various robes you can put on, with various abilities- at high levels of play, the PVP aspect is balanced, but at low-med levels, you can spam a few spells and always win since people don't know how to counter them- Versus mode is LODSA fun at high skill levels- huge skill roof- great physics and offense-defense mechanics- intuitive effects of your spellsI recommend it a lot, especially if it's on sale. About the DLCs? I'm not sure. Having the base game is enough imo, the DLCs are really worth it for the extra robes that you can have fun with.GET YER ROBES ON

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Magicka Original Release: 2011 Genre Tags: RPG; Action; Innovative; Lighthearted; Fantasy My Overall Grade: A- Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 9-20 hours Multiplayer Aspect: Optional Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Novelty seekers REVIEWMagicka is a very enjoyable game. Fun, funny, and challenging... it makes for a very amusing experience. The standard campaign is relatively brief, but there is a lot of DLC content. Some of it is cosmetic and can be ignored, but much of it provides actual content and you will likely want to pick it up to get the full experience. Magicka also makes for unique and enjoyable multiplayer gameplay, if you find some people to play with. As I alluded to, the innovation inherent in the main gameplay mechanics is the primary reason that Magicka is something worthy of being in your library. There isn’t much else quite like it, and absolutely nothing of the same caliber.  You have to rapidly press certain button combinations to cast various spells while simultaneously controlling your character and aiming in an isometric view. It is pretty unique and intense. I personally found it more comfortable with a controller, but it also works well with a standard keyboard and mouse set up.And while the exciting gameplay is definitely the soul of the game, it is also quite funny and charming too. The art style is very fitting to the mood of the game; and although the graphics aren’t the best, they feel appropriate. With the addition of the mumble language, silly plot, and hyperbole of blood/gore, the jovial nature of Magicka becomes clear. This lighthearted atmosphere synergizes well with the unique gameplay to create an experience that is incontestably fun.The key feature of the game being the innovative gameplay mechanics, I recommend anyone looking for some variety check it out if they haven’t already. I highly recommend playing with other people though; it’s much more fun and much less frustrating (since you can revive each other).Also the Versus and Survival modes are pretty fun, especially since the game supports local-coop (as in sitting on a couch with your friends, as it was in the old days).Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												Magicka is one of my favorite games, and one of the few that does a good job making you feel like a wizard.The Good:The crown jewel of Magicka's design is its spell creation system.  It was not the first video game to allow you to design spells by selecting the path, area of effect, effects, and intensities.  The Elder Scrolls: Arena had that in 1994, and there may be earlier examples I don't know about.  It may be the first to allow you to create spells on the fly.  It is also noteworthy for having no limits based on a mana pool or cooldowns.  Instead, the main balancing forces are enemy resistances and the destructive power of your own spells.  It's very easy to make a mistake and kill yourself or your allies.Magicka is also well known and loved for its voice acting.  Everyone speaks a mix of broken Swedish and jibberish.  Vlad is an over the top Romanian vampire in denial.  Death and Fafnir also sound great.  I would love to know what sort of processing they performed on their voices.Magicka has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard.  It's bombastic, complex, and memorable.  Unfortunately it may be hard to appreciate with it often being drowned out by the sounds of the chaos around you.The Bad:Magicka is very buggy, even by modern PC gaming standards.  Crashes and hangs are common.  Weapons and staves, which may be unique, frequently clip through the map and disappear into the void forever.  Players lose connection in online games often.  The DLC is even worse.  The Stars Are Left has an unpatched bug on the last level, where if you don't pass through the doors in the order the developers expected you to, not only does it crash, but it corrupts your save so you have to start that DLC over.  The fact that is still unpatched is shameful, by the way.Difficulty does not scale based on the number of players.  The main game isn't that difficult to get through solo, but some of the DLC is very hard without a full party.  I found the final fights in Dungeons and Daemons and The Stars Are Left to be impossible to solo.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												The 76 metascore is the result of what Magicka was when it came out: A hidden gem executed okey-ishly and with some bugs. But that's way too far from the game Magicka is today...Which is one of the best Local-Multiplayer/Co-Op/Versus games in all of Steam. I was a late buyer so I got to skip all the supposed bug-fest, but let me tell you this: Right now, Magicka is a blast to play with friends. Be it local or online multiplayer, co-op campaign or versus or survival, with keyboards or with controllers or any mix of all of the above. Aside from the super-robust level of multiplayer options, the game's campaigns (main and all of the DLCs) are amazing. The main campaign is filled with easter eggs, little details everywhere and stupendous and magnificent narrative comedy. I'll be frank and admit I haven't finished most DLCs yet (as I wait until all my buds can get together to finish them in one sitting), but I can tell you that The Stars Are Left, The Other Side of the Coin and Dungeons And Daemons are worth every penny.The quality for your money also applies for multiplayer-oriented DLC, which is cheap and adds lots of cool themes, robes with different stats and abilities and weapons that range from The Doctor's Screwdriver to Ak-47s and of course a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amount of staffs.The gameplay is a bit hard to explain as there are truly no games like Magicka: Top down isometric spell casting & mixing shmup with always-on friendly fire is the shortest way to put it. The long one is: You see your wizard from a top-down-with-an-angle perspective, you can cast 8 elements: Fire, Life, Electricity, Water, Cold, Earth, Arcana/Death, and "shield" which gives any combination of elements a defensive use of sorts. All this elements are on their own very weak but once you combine them you can get deadly creative. From mini-volcanoes that light enemies on fire and explode when touched to steam-compressed mines that send foes (and friends) flying away Team Rocket-style to Death-electric beams that freeze to freaking Meteor Showers to casting Death Itself (whom kills someone on-screen at random).Now remember that the game has always-on friendly fire. Yup, it's a madhouse.If Mario Party destroys friendships, Magicka will obliterate blood-related family ties. But in the nicest, funniest and best ways.As a lover of couch co-oping, well-executed games, friendship, and... well, games in general, I urge you, TRY MAGICKA. It's very unlikely you'lle ever regret it.Unless you have no friends, of course. Being burned/electrocuted/bombed-away/exploded into tiny pieces accidentally on purpose is not as much fun when a complete stranger does it.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												I don't think I've ever been so in love with a video game before...It's buggy, horribly optimized, and suffers from such bad models and animations that they make a joke of it (traveling through landscapes that showcase herds of sheep-facades propped up in the pastures, or riding upon noble steeds who seem to be from the finest wooden toy horse stock), and you won't give a damn about any of it.  The multiplayer is nearly impossible to set up and laggy almost to the point of unplayability once you do, but it's such vibrant, stupid and chaotic fun that you'll ignore such minor negatives in favor of the grander scheme of bumbling wizards.The innovative magic system is profoundly complex and joyously destructive to experiment with, and there's a very scientific glee involved with working out your trademark spell(s) or finding the coolest combinations to solve a particular problem.You'll also learn to develop a newfound respect for such veterans of the wizardry craft as Gandalf or Dumbledore...  When you recognize just how much obscenely destructive force you have at your unwitting fingertips, it's always impressive when you DON'T manage to disintegrate/melt yourself and everyone in a 4-mile radius when attempting to do something.While the game is fun enough on its own and the writing is of absolutely stellar class, with actually funny wit and some really quite unexpectedly subtle jokes and twists, this game excels at multiplayer.  Yes, the horribly-irritating-to-get-started multiplayer.My deepest recommendation is to play this game with 3 friends, preferably with none of you knowing your wizard staves from your rump bristles.  Idiocy and a vast array of destructive weaponry often lead to the best of times, and ignorance of your own strength is the perfect excuse for "accidentally" slaughtering everyone on your team.The game starts you off with a resurrection spell, and as with all spells and magic in this game there is neither a mana cost nor a cooldown of any sort...  And you'll be very happy that it is this way, as roughly 98% of player deaths are either self-induced or from friendly fire.  Or some wonderfully flashy combination of the two.Indeed, the greatest danger you face is not the foe in front of you, but rather your overeagerness to simultaneously shock, burn, freeze and meltingly explode the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ into his primary colors.  Positively philsophical, really.I have never for a moment regretted purchasing this game.  Indeed, my saddest moment was when it finally ended...  for the second or third time.  Along with all the DLC missions.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												There are not many games out there, that make a great wizardry game. They include basic spells with no creativity, no humor, and those ANNOYING magic bars! But, There is one game though, that is very different. Magicka offers fantastic creativity with your spells, as you have 8 elements to choose from: Water, Fire, Earth, Cold, Arcane, Lightning, Shield, and Life. And out of all those elements you can do 5 elements at a time to do spells at people, offering great creativity in the game. For example, you can combine Earth 3 times, and then you can do 2 fire, or Water and Cold and Water and Cold/Ice,Ice,  or Arcane And Water. Some elements don't mix like Lightning and Earth, but can combine 2 for 1, such as Water+Fire=Steam. The game also allows you to combine different spells together in order to make... "Magicks." Magicks are combinations of spells to make "Different" that are bigger and better, such as... "Summon Death, Meteor Shower, Summon Thunder, Teleport and more!" The game is full of humor in cutscenes and gameplay about violence, logic, references and silly stuff that happen all the time! Finally, the game has NO MAGIC BARS!!!!!!!!!!!!! YEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEY!!!!!!!!!!! Finally a mage game that doesn't have magic bars! Screw swords and hammers used all the time! Spam Meteor balls, Chain lightning Goblins, use Force Powers on Evil vampires, and EVEN MORE WITHOUT LIMIT!!!!!! The game has fun single player and multiplayer, offering co-op and fun at the same time. But the game is sometimes full of bugs such as going out of the map, character glitching, and others. The game is fun and I recommend it to people who like to push the limit with magic, have comedy and epic wizardy at the same time. So now guys i got to g- OH SHOOT!  You fell into a hole! Don't worry, remember the safe word is Banana!

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												This game really can't be taken seiously, with all of its references to other movies and games, and dry comedy  THIS IS SPARTA!!!! .  Just got an Assualt Rifle in a fantasy game, somehow.  Comedic story-telling aside, Magicka's elemental magic system ironically has a facinating science behind it, with many combinations of the 8 different types of Magic (Lightning, Water, Life, Arcane, Cold, Fire, Earth, and Shield). The game allows you to mix together different spells to form more potent and lethal spells (Water+Fire=Steam, Water+Cold=Ice), as well as enchant your weapon, cast upon yourself, or create an area of effect. With a "Magicks" spellbook, the game allows you to increase your speed, confuse an enemy, or summon a thunderstorm, and many others. The game also rewards and punishes you for different enemies, as you can electrocute enemies doused in water or wearing metal armor, or freeze wet enemies, or burn tree spirit golem things.I enjoy playing this game, and would definitely recomend or even buy Magicka for a friend.TL;DR, mix spells and burn things to the ground. Ice+Ice+Ice+Ice+Earth = ONE HIT K.O.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Magicka, follows in the tradition of a really cool top-down RPG. As a D&D RPG it does not disappoint, and the graphics are crisp, detailed and very well done. I thought going into this game it would be more cartoonish; Thankfully, I was completely wrong. The dialogue is what you would expect of a quality RPG, the learning curve is designed to make the game accessible to gamers of all stripes, and the story is interesting. All in all a value bundle. My only real con for this game, is the sheer amount micro-transaction DLC, such as; Individual sets of armor. Is this really necessary. The developers made a quality game, does it need to be micro-transactioned all to hell too? Other than that, pick it up if you like RPG's, you should have a good time with it.

												Note: This game been tried out and reviewed in Steam offline mode or on Consoles.This game is a surprisingly good and addictive game.It comes down to that you're basically a wizard character with an arsenal of 6 elemental spells you can use at any time.But that's just the tip.the spell casting system in this game is unbelievably clever. Allowing you to combine different types of elements to create new spells - the manual totes that there are thousands of possibilitiesThe game does seem kind of difficult to start and may be frustrating, but once you get the mechanic down, it is just plain fun worth the time & It has an online co-op where you can battle with up to 4 friends and even combine spells with themMagicka is at its best when you an at least one buddy are prepared to go on a satirical journey through a mock RPG land and laugh.This game is not designed to be overly challenging or serious, colors but fun. And it succeeds with colors.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												While writing I realised I made a rather large review, for the short version check my conclusion at the end.This without a doubt is the best wizard game i have ever played, sort of unfortunatly. I have always wanted a wizard game where you feel powerful, being able to destroy hundreds of enemies with unparraled power, but the problem i have always encountered is mana bars, a system I have always despised for reasons I wont go into here, or in the case of some games (Lichdom battlemage) being aimed for challenge.Here is where Magicka comes with no mana and is aimed for fun and funny moments. It uses its element systam allowing you to make your own spells, while also allowing more designed Magickas like Storms or summoning Zombies. Its all I could have asked for, and is great fun and is actually funny.Here comes the problems, it is designed for co-op with 2 to 4 players and enemy encounters dont change in anyway between the two, this means that riding solo is insanly difficult, also it is really easy to die due to its chaotic nature, its balanced in multiplayer with players being able to infinitly instanly revive buddies with no real reprocussions, single player you get one revive between checkpoints which are stretched out between many large enemy encounters. This leads to you needing to use overpowered robes (Sort of like choosing a new build) or cheesing the game solo, especially the final boss who is tanky, gives you little room to move, and has a insta kill black hole attack which sucks you in. But I still went on to complete the game by myself because it is that good.If you have any interest in a wizard game buy it, and try to get your friends to play since that is the superior experience, but even with all its flaws in single player it is still worth getting.

Posted: October 19, 2014
												If you want a game that takes itself seriously, this isn't for you.If you want a game that you can enjoy to the fullest on your own, this isn't for you either.Granted, while I usually do prefer playing games with friends, Magicka was really far from what my expectations of it were, and more often than not feels like a bit of a wasted potential for something that could've been really interesting in several ways. That said, I suppose it might just have been better that they didn't try to make this serious.Nevertheless, with my complaints aside, Magicka manages to make any group of friends have loads of fun for as long as the story lasts, and the whole element combination system is really, really amusing to use, moreover with other people to do it with. I can't praise the comic relief "plot" or the presentation much, but for what it's worth, I don't really regret buying it!

Posted: May 31, 2015
												I played both Magicka 1 and Magicka 2, and I'd simply recommend this game better. This is good for players with a good muscle memory. Magicka 2 is more noob friendly, and its watered down a lot. In this game you must know how to spam. Really you can't just spam whatever you must know exactly how to spam or else you'd be healing enemies. I like combining Steam and Lightning or Ice and Lightning in this game. You cannot do that in Magicka 2.This game requires a good strategy after a certain chapter! You can't just go and spam spells anymore. Some enemies appear having a weakness agains one or two elements and you really need to use it. In magicka 2 you just use Death + Fire aoe to win. No brainer.Humour is great, you're op, you can die of your op-ness, story is better than in M2 etc.The only cons I FIND annoying are-Multiplayer laggy as hell in versus(or in general)-Spell icon appearing/conjuring feels a bit unintuitive, but this is fixed if you know what you cast actually.-Graphics feel a bit outdated ( But really who the hell cares?)-It feels better done than magicka 2..

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 21
												Lots of games punish you hard for being a wizard. At the start of the game, you get your one or two spells, and then you have to pretend you're a fighter or run away useless.This is not one of those games. In this game, you actually feel like a wizard. The only consequences for letting off as many of your most overpowered spells as you can is that maybe one of your friends gets caught in the blast. But you're a mother effing wizard, so resurrect the poor sucker and keep going.There is a story, but the game doesn't really expect you to pay attention to it. You're a murder hobo on a quest to save the world by killing whatever happens to be in your way. But that's not the point of the game.The point of the game is the magic system. It's by far the most unique way of handling magic I've ever seen. It takes a bit of getting used to, but once you get the hang of it it is supremely satisfying to let of a huge string of different spells in quick succession, subtlety tweaking your spells to suit the situation.Or you could just spam QFASA over and over, if that's your thing.Final note: the game is really designed to be played in co-op. You can play single player, but you're missing out on the full experience.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Where to start, where to start...The insanely intricate magic system that offers a crazy amount of different spell combinations? The quirky humour that is cram-packed with references to popular culture and everything geek? The endearing colourful graphics that turn every second of looking at this game into pure joy? Or maybe the never-ending challenges, be it through several great DLCs or the long list of fun achievements? Because yes, this game, unlike so many, offers achievements that are actually that, real achievements that are either painfully challenging or simply extremely fun to get.Yet of course, while Magicka offers all that, it only truly unfolds its full potential when played with others. Personally I enjoy co-op most (accidental, yet sometimes not so unintentional, killing of your friends guaranteed thanks to friendly fire), but versus mode as well offers a good deal of entertainment.There is literally no excuse not to get and enjoy Magicka if you like video games and most certainly a bunch of good laughs.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												This little gem throws you into the robes of a wizard and sets you on a noble quest to save the world of Midgård from destruction. As a wizard, you are given power over 8 different elements, from which you may cast a vast array of spells by combining them in different ways. This mechanic is very well thought out, with elemental opposites that may or may not result in death if you're not careful, as well as radically different effects for different combinations providing plenty of depth in your spell casting. There are, however, some spell combinations which are obviously more powerful than others, oftentimes leaving no reason to use the others. Despite this, alternate spells do come in handy every once in a while, so don't be afraid to experiment with them.In regards to the story I'm not going to say much so that you can experience it all for yourself, but suffice it to say that it's very much an adventure of epic proportions and theres lots of content to enjoy. Every location and every boss feels unique and is fun to battle. While the adventure is generally supposed to be pretty serious, it's delivered in a silly and lighthearted manner, including humorous narration and funny NPC dialogue. Furthermore, the soundtrack fits in at every moment of the game - it's reminiscent of Lord of the Rings and it's certainly no worse for wear because of it. Booming and powerful when an action scene calls for it, quaint and quiet when it's calm, and with several other tracks to fill in moments of the game that don't quite fit into either category.Finally, there are several modes you can play with your friends and accidentally (read: not really on accident) kill your friends with a spell gone awry or something else. Always great fun to gib your buddies late on a friday night - and yes, if it's not your thing there are settings that change the gore. The game allows you to play the story mode in co-op, and there is also a "versus" mode, but I've yet to try the latter.In short, a great game to play on your own, fantastic with friends.Now hurry up and get it! Before they run out of cheese!

												Don't be fooled by the underwhelming screenshots shown on the store page. This game is high paced, action packed, and incredibly fluid. Adventure with your friends for maximum enjoyment.The game utilizes eight elements which you can combine to create an enormous number of effects. You and your friends can "cross the beams" and have mega powered attacks, massive explosions, and any number of other crazy effects.The story is a bit quirky but it's actually quite entertaining. There are "twists," drama, humor, and even the occasional moment of somber seriousness. The game can get quite difficult, and every battle leaves you feeling like an action movie hero.It's a great game on it's own, but it's an unbeatable experience with your friends.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												[+8] Clever element-combination system. You use various elements to make a composite spell. For example; use rock and arcane to make an arcane bomb, then add fire to make an incendiary arcane bomb. Combine water with cold to make ice shards, throw in lightning to make electric ice shards.[+4] Slapstick humour. Casting spells is the very definition of spray-and-pay, and since it's designed for co-op, you will likely have lots of fun setting your friends on fire.[+2] Also a funny story. Silly, enjoyable medieval romp, a bit like Discworld with less subtlety.[-2] Problems. While it's obvious why the funny bugs (like bouncing weapons) were kept in, it crashes a little more frequently than the average game. Also organising co-op matches can be a pain sometimes.[-2] Bit of an eyesore. Environments bland, models and animations a bit sloppy. No real distinct art style.OVERALL SCORE: +10

content:
Posted: October 26, 2013
												Although I admire the novel control system in Magicka, I didn't enjoy playing this game. It feels too much like work. And... I kind of suck at it.I think I'd be more efficient and struggle less with a few more levels of play, but I don't feel compelled to keep trying. The gameplay is uncreative ARPG, and I find the humor too juvenile to entertain. The warmed-over "Swedish Chef" mock-language is painful and unfunny.I do think Magicka has a good pricing model. The base game is cheap ($10, and on sale for practically free all the time), and the DLC is affordable. You can keep paying for more content at your own pace until you get bored. This works for me. Good system. It's also a decent "beer and pretzels" co-op game; a way to kill a couple hours with friends.So... given the low price point, if you are looking for a co-op game, I would recommend Magicka with these reservations. It wasn't my cup of tea, but for a few bucks, it's hard to pass up.

												Loads of fun. content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
Magicka Left ArmI believe most gamers know what "Nintendo Thumb" is. For those who don't, it is when you've been been using the D-pad or Gamepad for such a long time that blisters and swellings started to appear on your thumbs or other fingers. Well, having mentioned "Nintendo Thumb", may I introduce a new term to you - the "Magicka Left Arm". This "Magicka Left Arm" is the situation where you've been playing Magicka for such a long time that, when you wake up the very next day, your left arm started to become sore and numb and, in extreme situations such as mine, you cannot move your left arm for the whole day. Yes, this has happened and I shall tell you why.First of all, allow me to begin by describing the game mechanism. It is not wrong to say that this game is based on the concept of conventional Diablo-like RPG. You control a character, nameless and hooded, and you roam around the top-down world by pointing and clicking at locations with your mouse. You are free to run around and whack enemies using your melee weapon, though it is not recommended to do so as you will die like a popcorn. What you can, and should, do is to cast Spells and Magick. Notice how Magick is spelt? It is, of course, different from your typical Diablo-type Magic. In Magicka, Spells and Magicks do not require mana. They are formed and casted based upon 8 different basic elements: Water, Life, Shield, Cold, Lightling, Arcane, Earth and Fire. Each of these elements are bonded to they keys "Q, W, E, R, A, S, D, F" respectively. (There are two advanced elements: Steam and Ice, formed by combining Water + Fire and Water + Ice respectively) You can cast Spells, such as the "Super Steam Lightling Beam" by first pressing the combination "Q, F, Q, F, Q, F, A, S" and then followed by right clicking. In that manner, a strong beam will shoot towards the direction your mouse is pointing towards. There are many others, and you can experiment more with them once you are in game, though I believe this will give you a general concept on spell casting.As for Magicks, they are special magics that can be casted by forming a specific elemental combination and then pressing <space>. For example, if I want to summon an elemental, I will have to press "S, E, D, Q, F, S, <space>". However, one single elemental is too weak and it will be annihilated with in a matter of seconds. So, what did I do? More elementals, of course! After starting the game for a while, I can be seen pressing this elemental summoning sequence repeatedly. I'll be trying to cast 20 or so elementals in a couple of seconds, watch them fight to their deaths while hiding in a shield (opps), and repeat the process. And that, my dear reader, is where I got my "Magicka Left Arm" after 6 hours of game play straight. Don't get me wrong. I am not saying that you have to spam elementals like me. I personally like to take the easy way out, and watching a bunch of kamikaze comandos fight for me can be quite entertaining. There are many other ways to complete the game, and I will give you the liberity to figure it out for yourself. But then and again, you can be quite certain that your left hand will be quite busy throughout the game. This the fun part of the game, and this experience is what make this game worthwhile. The graphics is not much of a looker (look at the screenshots) and the jokes, though initially creative and great, can get quite cheesy in the long run. Great game if you want to enjoy something light and humourous, though watch out for the "Magicka Left Arm". You've been warned - spell casting can be extremely addictive.

content:
Posted: April 6
Great game for anybody who likes magic, strategy, silliness, and chaos.    The comedy is great and the difficulty is perfect, so that the game is challenging but also easy, in that you can run into battle with a flaming sword or throw massive boulders to squash anyone in your path, or you can put together complex spells and chain them together, Ex. Creating rain clouds to soak your enemies then fry them with lightning.   The game is without a doubt best played multiplayer. The game features great multiplayer, and I have experienced little to no lag at all. There are a lot of game modes, from pvp to vietnam, and each is really fun.   The game's story is linear and gets boring after a few runs, but all dialog and most cutscenes can be skipped and get you right into the action.    The graphics are simple and can be run on even the worst computers, given you just lower the resolution, But the game still looks beautiful and creates a captivating world.   And of course the game and all DLC are super cheap (and worth it).Also, if you are still not sure, you should check out The Yogscast and TotalBiscuit's series on this game, which is only a fraction of the fun this game can offer.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
Product received for free
												Magicka is an action-adventure game,  where you play as a magician who still needs to learn how to use  spell combinations. The real objective of the game is: that you need to defeat the evil with your mighty spells and side-arm.In my opinion the game looks like Runescape (in a positive way). Magicka starts with eight spells at the beginning and you’ll get a staff and a sword to wield, there are also another powerful weapons which the creatures could drop or hidden somewhere over the map.In the game there are evil creatures that were made by a powerful wizard, Grimnir. The wizard wanted to spread eternal peace to the world but the order expelled him because of his ambitions. Grimnir was imprisoned at the World’s End. My first time I’ve played Magicka I needed to go into a room below me, but I was just stupid enough that I didn’t read what they asked me to do. So I’ve spent like four minutes of my live to find the damn room. The reason: there was a party that was made for me so I was in a hurry because some guys wanted to eat all the cheese there were all by themselves. I aren’t a great fan of cheese so I didn’t care if they ate it. My impressions I’ve made so far.The game is made with sarcastic jokes, which I didn’t found funny (except one tip: drink not when you drive, is that a tip for a game that has no cars)? I’ve played the game alone until chapter four and I died like eight times, with a few rages. I was proud of myself that I could beat the first chapter. Got pain in my hand, because of spamming casting the spells upon the enemy.The Pros and Cons of the game.Pros:-	The game is fun to play with friends or with people all around the world-	The graphics are admirable -	The game got trading cards -	The developers tried his best to make some jokes, but it didn’t work out somehow-	The game got some nice background soundsCons: -	The game is hard to play, when you play the game all by yourselves-	The voice of the people sounds like they are drunk all the time-	Sometimes the screen turns black when you start the game, but you can find an easy fix that will prevent it from  hapening on youtubeI’d say give this game a chance and buy it only if you play the game online with friends or with people all around the world.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												Magicka was quite the entertaining game that I didn't expect it to be. I expected a short 5 hourish game that would be fun for like the first 2 hours. I was very wrong. I ended up playing through the whole adventure mode of Magicka with a friend, so in co-op, and it was quite a bit of fun.To start, Magicka has great graphics and spell effects and animations. Everything about the game looks good. Another thing that makes Magicka so good is that there are so many different orb combinations to make different spells, effects, and Magicka. When I mean there are so many different combinations, I mean that there are legit possibly over 100 differnt unique and tiered spells and Magicka you can cast. Not only that, but each spell combination often features its own unique graphical effect and animation. Couple this with some other weather and terrain, the game has a really a super in depth spell casting system.Magicka has a pretty random story, but it is pretty funny in places. The gameplay is pretty entertaining and the difficulty level increases perfectly for the most part. Although some times there are some abnormally easy bosses while some of the mob fights were annoyingly hard. Overall, Magicka does a very good job with checkpoints too so you do not feel super punished when you screw around and die. As I mentioned before, I played this game with a friend. I strongly recommend that you play Magicka with a friend or two or three because there are so many little things that make playing with more people more fun. For one, the revive is a clutch coop spell and there are so many more spells that can be comboed.Overall a good and fun game that you should play with your friends. I really did not find any flaws to this game apart from the occasional crash.Rating: 8.8/10Recommend Price: $5 or under

												Pros:-There are no Cons!!!This game is brilliant on how it handles simplistic ideas and amazing references and creates an incredibly unique and fun game. content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
This is another very long review. If you just want a summary of my reasons for why I recommend this game skip to Results and read from there.Magicka by Arrowhead Game Studios is an interesting game that really keeps you on your toes. I use the word interesting because this game has some great concepts although I could easily see them as potential weaknesses to some people. Magicka requires you to use physics and chemistry to create spells and solve puzzles. These include such concepts as freezing rivers, powering generators, and combining elements to create powerful spells. The Campaign:You play as one of four wizards who are a part of the Order of Magick. You start their adventure in Castle Alderheim where you are given a quest to save the world. The game includes twelve chapters, which pull you through time and space. You are led by your guide Vlad, possibly a vampire, who continuously points you in the right direction. The campaign requires you to fight many bosses who require different tactics to beat: Jormungandr, Jotunn, The Warlock, Khan, Grimnir, The Aristocrats, Vlad, Death, Fafnir, Grimnir, and Assatur. There are many DLC packs which allow you to play many campaigns and experience a full new game. The campaign has funny dialogue which speaks between English and gibberish. The campaign is rather cut and dry. Each level is essentially the same concept, basically fight the enemies and beat the level. Yet again, this is how most games that fit into this genre seem to be. There are many funny jokes, references, and characters which make this game a blast to play through. In fact one of the Wizards you can select is a Space Marine from the 40k series (plus there are all these game references in the campaign). Gameplay:The enemies tend to repeat themselves and throughout the campaign you typically be using the same spells over again. What most people don’t seem to mention is the difficulty of this game. This game is not easy in any sense of the word, in fact even if you play with more people the game just gets harder. With latency issues and friendly fire can result in a very tough campaign where you will kill your friends more than your enemies. If you play the game solo it can be very difficult and with the patches and updates is even harder now than it was before. There is no mana, no leveling up, and pretty much no real loot. You may find a few weapons throughout the campaign, but they are not going to make a huge difference to how you play the campaign. I personally played the whole game with the M60, but other than that all the weapons seemed to be just as effective as the ones I start with. Useful Advice:Magicka REQUIRES a good keyboard. This keyboard preferably should be a gaming keyboard and should not be wireless (unless it’s a wireless gaming keyboard). In order to preform spells and move at the same time Magicka sometimes requires you to use more keys than you have fingers. If your keyboard cannot handle multiple key-presses then you will not be able to play this game. I would recommend playing this game with a macro-enabled keyboard/mouse in order to fully enjoy the actual campaign. In fact the game can be so difficult that even with macros you will more than likely not succeed in a mission on your first attempt. There are many spell combinations with some of them being very hard to figure out. Results:If you like bird’s eye view co-op action adventures then this could be a good choice for you. Make sure you are well equipped, ready for a hard challenge, and have some friends. This is a fun campaign, with witty dialogue, and amazing spell casting. If you have a great memory for up to eight letter combinations then you’ll be very good at this game. If I were you I’d play the game with macros, essentially that’s like putting the game from “Insane” down to “Hard Difficulty”.Pros:+Spell combinations are almost endless+Funny dialogue, hilarious references, and a great story.+Many items you can find in the game (with different bonuses and special spells)+Lots of wizards to select from with different weapons and base attributes+Offers four player co-op experience+Nice graphics and smooth visuals+Interesting boss fights which require a variety of different strategies+Puzzles and mysteries to solve within each level+Lots of DLC with new story and characters abound+Rather long campaign+NO GRINDINGCons:-Insanely difficult (especially if you solo or co-op without experts).-Spell combinations can be rather cumbersome (not a game for people who are not good with memorizing eight letter combinations).-If you are not an expert at memory you typically end up using the same spell through the entire game (rock, rock, rock, rock, rock). -I sometimes had issue with random lag in the main menu screen (nothing game-breaking, but could get infuriating sometimes).

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												You are a mage that can cast spells using the various elements.  The elements can stack together to enhance your spells, and some combinations can be learned to cause special abilities, such as slow time, increase movement speed, revive a fallen teammate, summon a tornado, etc.  You can cast your magicks onto your weapon to give your weapon increased damage, cast in a circle around you to affect all characters nearby, or simply cast in front of you.Each element has something that will counter it, so not all combinations are possible.  Further, if you try to use one of these when you have an opposites status effect applied (like trying to use lightning when wet), you'll cause damage to yourself!  As an added bonus, all of your spells can also hurt your other party members, so you need to be careful not to kill your friends.I absolutely enjoyed this game.  The enemies are varied throughout each chapter and each has their own weaknesses you need to discover.  The game keeps you on your toes while allowing you to constantly learn new ways to summon magicks.  The only negative I can say about this game is that it has a terribly steep learning curve.  I played co-op with someone who had played once before and it took me several chapters before I finally understood how all the magicks worked together and could actually contribute effectively to the combat.  I enjoyed these early chapters just as much as the later chapters despite not really knowing what I was doing.Another negative about this game (that can be completely ignored) is that the gamepad controls are absolutely terrible.  Literally any other control setup would have been better than the set gamepad controls.  I prefer gamepad, but I had to play with keyboard and mouse.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												In Magicka, you're a wizard. You've got eight elements that you can stack up, mix, multiply, and unleash. You can cast them at goblins, cast them at anything next to you, cast them at your specially blunted sword, cast them at your own face.Singleplayer mode is a light comic fantasy, narrated by your dodgy mentor, Vlad. The black-clad Romanian wizard keeps pointing out that he's not a vampire, and making bad puns about sinking his teeth into things. It's a mix of satire and pop culture references that'll have you smirking dangerously throughout. Lots of care has gone into the way the elements combine and contort in your spells. Combinations shape the form (Missile? Beam? Cone? Wall?) and function (Healing? Burning? Shielding? Exploding? Freezing? Drenching? Zapping?) of each glorious experiment. There's enough variety for every wizard to have his or her own favourite attack style. Mine is a steamy lightning beam that scalds you before dealing bonus lightning damage from the water element in steam.Concocting these spells is a little confusing at first, as you're commanding eight elements across eight keys, but you're rarely faced with enemies that can't be killed by particular elements. Button mashing will get you far, and a mistake might just surprise you. The environments are top-down, linear jaunts through bright and breezy fantasy tropes: forests full of goblins, orcish trenches, swamps, mines, the land of the dead. Wander off the beaten path, and you can find powerful equipment and new magic spell recipes that reach beyond the scope of your regular elemental concoctions - spells such as Revive and Teleport.Singleplayer will soon wear thin, sadly. It's not that you can't beat it with the right spells and an awful lot of goes – it's that if you make a mistake and burst like a sticky water balloon, you get chucked back to the last checkpoint you reached. In once case, that involves fighting three big groups of face-pounding orcs and one-hit-smash-to-deathing ogres, in a row, before you hit another checkpoint. If you quit before you complete that level (perhaps out of, ooh, say, frustration), you'll have to start it all over again when you boot up the game again. Ultimately, you'll hit this annoying boss or that overpowered yeti thing or this boring underworld level and you'll just give up on singleplayer. Then you'll turn to multiplayer. And multiplayer is good, when it works. If you've got a few networked computers and three eager friends with Magicka on their Steam accounts, you can enjoy the splendour of four death lasers combining neatly into a super-beam that bursts ogres in seconds. You can have tactics and gambits and laugh as they end with one wizard left, deciding if he wants your gear before he resurrects you.The bulk of us, however, will be butting our heads against the brick wall of online multiplayer. At the time of writing, developers Arrowhead have been releasing patches every 24 hours, and they're gradually improving on the terrible connectivity issues. Despite their efforts, you no sooner host a game than Steam Chat dies, Skype calls drop, and flatmates start inspecting the router for flashing lights. For a game so reliant on multiplayer to be fun, there are lots of missed opportunities. There's no chapter select function, no joining mid-session for latecomers or disconnected players, no voice chat, no dedicated servers, and tons of lengthy, wordy cutscenes that only the host can skip. Get it working, and it's great. For £8, you'll get your money's worth before everyone forgets about it. But it could have been game of the year material! Silly wizards.THE VERDICT 69/100MAGICKAConfused and buggy, but very entertaining under the right circumstances. Bring friends.

In cooperative volume of butthurt and fun only increases, so buy the game, and you will get large amount of fun time :)

content:
Posted: February 12, 2011
												It's Diablo without a level up system, and like Diablo, it's best played with friends.  Travel through 13 stages with 8 different schools of magic that can be combined to make a staggering number of combat strategies against enemies.  Spells and restoring friends from death costs nothing, so the challenge comes from your ability to work as a team and not screw up.  Believe me when I say though that screwing up is a LOT harder not to do than you think.  Combining magic and then deciding how to excecute it while being chased by enemies often makes you mess up your combination and worse yet, your friends can very easily be caught in the crossfire, or spells that don't mix in certain situations will cause a terrible backfire and insta-kill them.  Again, there's no cost to resurrecting your friends, but some players could become frustrated from being killed by their friends more than their enemies.  $10 is well worth a game like this, so grab your friends and see how well you work together!

												Kill things with lightning, kill things with the 7 things that aren't lightning, freeze your friends, summon rocks to shatter your friends, ignore their pleas for you to revive them!Magicka is a game with water, life, shield, cold, lightning, arcane, earth and fire. Now obviously summoning cold and water makes ice, or summoning fire and water makes steam, but you can make a life beam with water infused into it, healing and wetting your friends and making them succeptable to zapping them with special abilities like steam, lightning, arcane, lightning to do 15,000 damage!Now, this isn't just a game where you can kill your friends - there's a story where everyone speaks all bouncy and you can kill all the NPCs with crazy combos that do varying amounts of damage and it's kind of tricky to get them right. But that's for singleplayer; if you have friends you will literally want to kill them, kill them and then feel better.Ruin everything - Magicka.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2012
												Magicka is an extremely fresh take on a very tired genre. The top-down Action RPG. It replaces the standard combat with one of the most innovative spell casting system I've ever seen in a game. Eight different elements that can be combined and used in a myriad of logical and easy to understand ways. Firing lightning at your enemies is more effective if you dose them with water first, combining cold and water makes you shoot ice shards and so on. It is easy to learn and easy to use even if some of the higher tier spells require a bit of practice.The graphics are simple but functional and the sound is somewhat lacking, the characters speaking some perverted form of Finnish mixed in with a good deal of gibberish.The storyline and characters are as random as it gets and the entire game is filled to the rim with old pop culture references. A little fun but not much, this is a game that should be played for the gameplay and nothing else.A great buy, especially with friends.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												I would like to give this game a good review because it can be a lot of fun.  Unfortunately there are far too many problems with this game for me to recommend a purchase.  The multiplayer is very strange.  There are often connection issues, and glitches during multiplayer.  I had to start at least half of the the levels over due to glithes.  This wouldn't be such a big problem if the game was balanced for singe player, but the game doesn't seem to scale in difficulty whether you are playing with one or four players.  I found some sections of the game almost unplayable because I couldn't connect with a friend in multiplayer and the enemies were so numerous the only way I could win was by cheesing the enemies and trying to glitch out their AI. The second problem is that the game is horribly balanced.  I can go through a level and kill everything no problem and then get to a group of regular enemies that one shot me no matter what.  Then I'll get to the boss and kill him in like 2 hits.  It's very strange.  The levels don't seem to get harder other then just throwing more enemies at you.  The third problem I had is that the game runs very choppily even on high end machines.  The graphics are not very good, but my computer and all of my friends comptuers will run this game very very slowly at times.  Even if the framrate is quite high, it will take quite a while for the game to catch up to my input.  The game is quite interesting, and the spells work great and look cool.  I really liked some of the time I spent playing this game, but frustration with the glitches and performance and balancing issues made this game almost unplayable.  I will be looking at magicka 2 to see if these issues were addressed, because the idea is there, the technical side just needs to catch up.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												Magicka is an absolute-fun game, made as well for solo player or coop, despiteI'd tell you to go with just 1 friend (or 2) to avoid making game too easy. Magicka takes all the RPG cliches and uses them as it satirizes all of them at once, which is  (somehow) one of the strongest point in the storyline.The growing up system is another strong point; instead of getting more hp or atack or♥♥♥♥♥♥ you'll just learn new magicks, which are just special combinations of your elements, and you'lll become faster at memorizing and using them.  You'll have to solve all your adventure with "only" your 8 elements, their possible combos and the way you cast them, which will make the diference between a vulcano crater, a burning sword or a burning stone armor. Anyways, this game uses simple concepts and turns them agains themselves. It's a mastercraft  with charismatic characters, funny dialogues, a decent plot and tons of friendly fire.It has just 2 bad points: First of all, it has good days whenever everything works fine, and bad days, with many crashes and/or bugs. On the other hand, there is something horrible: it has HUNDRED OF DLCs!!!! So despite many of them are just run&andkill games (and are not worth paying), you can still have MOAR MAGICKA, MOAR FUN AND MOAR ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥-HIENA LAUGH WITH YOUR BUDYS.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												This game is actually some of the most fun I've ever had, logical spell system with tons of versatility and combinations, you combine elements and can then cast them on yourself, as an AOE or directly, you can also store the "spell" in your weapon which will then be activated next time you use it to strike. This game is fun with friends and alone, especially given how easy it is to hit your friends with a bit of "friendly" fire... and or accidentally kill yourself. There are also a few special spells that can be learned via items found, these spells require the combination and are then executed with a button press. Such as reviving one of your friends who you probably just blew up a moment ago...I think it's got lots of replay value, the story is cute and funny with tons of references to the genre. The game is in and of itself a bit of a parody. I personally don't have any issues or criticisms of the game, it's not perfect, but the quirks are all part of its charm.  I would recommend it to anyone that has a sense of humour, especially if you have some knowledge about other games in similar genres. It's especially fun with a group of friends (up to 4) but is still very entertaining on your own. I personally found it pretty additive.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												This game is my favourite representation of a magic system. In a lot of movies and games the characters mention that magic is "dangerous" and can be harmful to yourself and others. This is THE GAME that represents the dangers of magic. The amount of times I've killed myself using lightning while being wet or summoning a boulder to crush me where I stand are numerous. The balance of simplicity of no levelling, only slight spell unlocks or item pickups and the complexity of having to mix and remember each spell is great. This game is most fun playing in coop which is also a lot easier than trying to overcome the bosses alone. Also great for LANs!

Posted: September 17, 2014
												This game will change the way your friends think of you. If you have a friend that is serious about playing this game, and you are NOT like-minded, s/he will hate you forever. One of the best magicks in the game(in my opinion), thunder bolt, is prone to freak accidents. Example, you and your friend are traveling and see an orge. Naturally, you cast thunder bolt, but instead of hitting the ogre, it hits your friend. This will happen over and over and over. So, this game can, has, and WILL ruin some friendships. But overall the gameplay is smooth, it's challenging, and more fun with more people.                                                                                    You've been warned.P.S. I've come to appreciate wizards/sorcerers/magicians more because of this game.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												The first thing that I noticed about the game was it's sense of humor.It doesn't take itself seriously and it's great!The storyline is packed with jokes and has a humorous plot-line.One of the only things that I didn't like about the game were the controls.They felt clunky and unresponsive at times.It's nothing major but I feel like they could have done a better job.Also some levels felt badly scripted and had a decent amount of bugs or graphic glitches.Magicka offers you a great deal of spell combination,a lot of customization and tons of enemies to kill! I feel like Magicka has too many DLCs but the game itself has a lot of content already.As a singleplayer game...it's kinda boring after awhile.It's the Multiplayer aspect of it that makes it a great game.It is a okey-ish experience as a singleplayer game but I really feel that it was built as a multiplayer.Magicka is a fun experience either way and you should at least try the base game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Magicka is a game where you are a wizard, trying to conjure spells using elements. The catch is that multiple combinations yield multiple spells, most of which will severely injure yourself and your teammates. The goodYou are given from start, after a quick tutorial on the basics, all the elements. This allows you to beat the game with anything.Combining elements is the key factor of the game, where you can cast a stone armor to protect yourself and lay healing mines for your teammate who crushes enemies using a steam-electric-arcane beam. Without a mana or cooldown system.there are some hidden goodies to look for, some only for the sake of it, like the mooses, or magicks, a spell that has to be entered in the right order.Magicks are unlockable combinations that are far more powerful and/or unique than your normal spells. From slowing time to freezing the entire screen, or as simple as a teleport of flammable oil. They serve the purpose of progression, and one is even a plot point of the game.The game is also a living pile of references, ranging to movies to games. If you like to see that kind of stuff, it's plenty in this game.The badThe plot is simple: Your goal is to defeat the main wizard baddie. No heavy plot twists or anything.The game is also filled with bugs, bust most of them are fixed within seconds. Gamebreaking bugs can be fixed with an easy restart, which will take you a few screens back. The netcode tend to be laggy for the clients, even with low ping.Most player characters are DLC, but most of them are simple reskins with no unbalanced stats. Some extra content are also DLC-only. The ugly  Sometimes the physics are wonky, with the knockback being powerful enough to knock your wizard several meters in the air. You can even reach spots you weren't meant to this way.Friendly-fire is also a key factor in the game, which can get problematic in certain situations, such as in tight spaces or a miscast. Hilarity can ensue if the wonky physics kick in.There may or may not be some plot holes around. Not that relevant, since the plot is already an excuse to cast stuff around.Some bosses can be one-shotted. While some can provide a worthwhile fight, some can be downed in seconds. However, one-shotting a boss requires some skill (and luck), and can be satisfying if you did it right.NutshellGrab this game if you got the coin and friends to play with. I still haven't played through all the chapters and DLC-content, but the fun-factor I had playing with my friend is undeniable. Yes, there will be rage over that single miscast, yes, there will be random deathmatches when someone's♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and yes, there will be fooling around whenever there's the chance to. And bugs. And that's it's charm. There's no problem with those, since players can be revived in a matter of seconds. The fun from this game came from laughing about failures of each other and the good times you spent with them, and when seriousness kicks in when a horde of NPCS appear and you enter a tactical approach to them. If you just care about goofing with your friends in a co-op game, Magicka is there.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												This game is GREAT. The campaign is big enough to pleasure you (i still havent completed it after about 5 hours). There are a lot of twists to the story and its also pretty funny to hear a vampire talking gibberish :P.There is also COOP (through the whole story) and there is PVP however i rarely ever find the people for it. The very few matches i have played in the multiplayer were amazing though...if only more people would be interested in the PVP section of this game it would have been a much better experience. The casting system is great and its something fresh and unique compared to other games. You can enchant your weapon , create walls, create a magickal barrier around you, create an armor for your body with the power of earth or just use the same combinations with a few changes to simply send massive fiery earth rocks to your opponents (thats my fav). If you get tired of the campaign or you finish it and want more...there are loads of dlcs you can buy :)

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												This is, hands down, the single most hilarious multiplayer experience you will ever have in your life. You can murder your friends horribly (whether you want to or not)! You can help your friends (you will still murder them horribly whether you want to or not)!You have access to 8 magic elements and combine them, on the fly, into various combinations and then let your spells fly... this usually has unpredictable and horrible results. On top of the various combinations of 8 elements you can then cast the spell on yourself, as an AOE, or on others... ya know, just because there wasn't enough variety to begin with. You'll quickly find a handful that work and, as you play more and more, grow comfortable and branch out to become more skilled in your ability to accidentally screw your friends over utterly. Lucky for you it's consequence free and revive takes mere seconds so it's all taken in stride and good humor.If you're looking for a ridiculous, over the top, "accidentally massacre everyone you hold dear" gaming experience then I'd highly recommend it. Don't forget, the safeword is BANANA!

This allows you to beat the game with anything.Combining elements is the key factor of the game, where you can cast a stone armor to protect yourself and lay healing mines for your teammate who crushes enemies using a steam-electric-arcane beam. Without a mana or cooldown system.there are some hidden goodies to look for, some only for the sake of it, like the mooses, or magicks, a spell that has to be entered in the right order.Magicks are unlockable combinations that are far more powerful and/or unique than your normal spells. From slowing time to freezing the entire screen, or as simple as a teleport of flammable oil. They serve the purpose of progression, and one is even a plot point of the game.The game is also a living pile of references, ranging to movies to games. If you like to see that kind of stuff, it's plenty in this game.The badThe plot is simple: Your goal is to defeat the main wizard baddie. No heavy plot twists or anything.The game is also filled with bugs, bust most of them are fixed within seconds. Gamebreaking bugs can be fixed with an easy restart, which will take you a few screens back. The netcode tend to be laggy for the clients, even with low ping.Most player characters are DLC, but most of them are simple reskins with no unbalanced stats. Some extra content are also DLC-only. The ugly  Sometimes the physics are wonky, with the knockback being powerful enough to knock your wizard several meters in the air. You can even reach spots you weren't meant to this way.Friendly-fire is also a key factor in the game, which can get problematic in certain situations, such as in tight spaces or a miscast. Hilarity can ensue if the wonky physics kick in.There may or may not be some plot holes around. Not that relevant, since the plot is already an excuse to cast stuff around.Some bosses can be one-shotted. While some can provide a worthwhile fight, some can be downed in seconds. However, one-shotting a boss requires some skill (and luck), and can be satisfying if you did it right.NutshellGrab this game if you got the coin and friends to play with. I still haven't played through all the chapters and DLC-content, but the fun-factor I had playing with my friend is undeniable. Yes, there will be rage over that single miscast, yes, there will be random deathmatches when someone's♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and yes, there will be fooling around whenever there's the chance to. And bugs. And that's it's charm. There's no problem with those, since players can be revived in a matter of seconds. The fun from this game came from laughing about failures of each other and the good times you spent with them, and when seriousness kicks in when a horde of NPCS appear and you enter a tactical approach to them. If you just care about goofing with your friends in a co-op game, Magicka is there.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												You are a wizard, a damn powerful, idiotic wizard whose given the command of eight elements to combine in any order of your imagination. It will most likely work, but like an idiot's imagination, it will hurt and kill you. This game is simply amazing, it's more than worth the "I may aswell try it" that can be thrown at a lot of games. Starting off with a small/short tutorial to unlock your magic or 'elements' (of which you can skip if you wish), you'll be thrown into the harsh and dangerous world filled with carboard cutouts of sheep, non-vampires and ever-trusting villagers in order to... Well, save it. (No spoilers!)But gameplay wise, it is diffcult to get used to. The vast combinations of spells pared with the movement and aiming could be the only thing to put someone off. Then again, give it time and you may find yourself loving the ongoing humor behind every unlocked door, the music which helps set the atmosphere like any great fantasy game and the endless comical refferences that just adds to the "Ha! I know that one" that reels you in.Multiplayer wise, because you CAN play with 3 other people within the storymode, versus and challenge mode. Yes, you may have connection issuse or lag issues, that's a downside. But! If you should find yourself with your (soon to be ex)friends starting off a story... It may take you longer than you think. This may be the only game that gets harder the more people you have, soley because you end up killing each other on purpose. Truth be told, you can have a lot of laughs without commiting to actually completing this game, to which it only makes it more exciting if you choose to.For anyone whose played a classic console game and thought "Wow, I wished they made games like this again." Then Magicka is for you. The elements of a classic are certainly there. For me personaly, it's just a game I feel I want to come back to time and time again 'just because'.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Magicka is a mostly cooperative (friendly fire is on) game about combining elements to create magic spells. It supports up to 4 player multiplayer with a adventure, challenge, and versus mode. The way the magic spells work is you have 6 slots to put elements in, and whatever combination you put in is mixed to create a unique spell. There are literally unlimited spell combinations, so there's tons of diversity. There's also books scattered around where you can find these things called Magicks, these are pre-set spells that do special things (some notable ones are summons, vortex, rain/thunderstorm/blizzard, ect). There are also many robes you can select aswell, they have special perks and downsides that make them unique from eachother (like immunity/weakness to some elements). The campaign could last you a good 4-5 hours with added DLC campaigns as well to add on to it. There are A LOT of DLC for this game, mostly PVP maps and robes, these are NOT needed and you should only get them if you feel like you would like those robes/maps or want to support the developer but the campaign DLCs are a must have in my opinion. People say this game is a buggy mess, and it is, but the glitches you may encounter are actually entertaining. The developer have worked hard and patched out most of the game ruining ones, so there's not much to worry about. Get this game, it's worth your money if you have friends to play it with.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Intro: This is a game that really benefited from having a demo. I enjoyed it so much while trying it out that I stopped and purchased it.The game can be fun alone, but I highly really recommend multiplayer for this one. Host your own room and play through the story while people drop in and out. If you have a few gamepads and friends you can also play locally on the same PC. Its a ton of fun either way.Gameplay: Magicka's gameplay is pretty entertaining. It has a neat magic system with lots of possibilities and a bunch of weapons you can come across. Loads of different characters. A bunch of game modes. A few different campaigns, some mini-campaigns, pvp arenas, and survival maps. Every mode is great fun to play and there's really a ton of content here. Just playing random multiplayer games can be a blast.Music & Visuals: The music was fitting, but nothing too memorial. The production was good nonetheless. I liked the artstyle. It was pretty and you can turn the gore off if that bothers you or if someone younger is going to play with you. Looks pretty nice overall.Story: The story was solid. Each campaign has its own. Its not really anything special, but its something there and gives you a goal.PC Version: Game runs pretty fine for the most part.I remember extremely high pings would cause multiplayer to crash. This may have been fixed as it was many years back, but as long as everyone was under 200ms then I didn't run into problems. Gamepads work fine with the game, though kb+m is a bit easier.One thing that some may not like - Magicka is one of those games with way too much DLC, but there's still a lot in the default game. Your best bet is buying the full bundle though during a large discount in a sale. I know some people can't stand loads of DLC, but it actually adds quite a lot without being too pricey.Conclusion: Overall its a fun game to play and has a lot of replay value. Go for it, especially if you have some friends to play with. My hours on the game are somewhat low, but its definitely something I'd play again if any of my friends were ever interested.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game, and I have spent several hours with it, but it was not a good game at all. Sure, spells are fun to cast here and there, but using the keyboard in such a manner, trying to remember what it seems hundreds of spells in the blink of an eye, is no where possible, which means you end up using a few spells that you can remember over and over again.This ruins the intent of the spells, because you can't type "FQFQAAS" or "DQDQDQRUPYOURRSE" when the game is constantly spamming you with foe. "Good players" will tell you to change your tactic, but doing some missions over and over again just to face another death one second close to victory, just takes away your mood entirely. Some missions you can't even complete without buying a better robe. So, the tactic here is: "Buy an upgrade" to advance. Real smooth.There is only one difficult setting which is "hard" or "insane", whatever you prefer, and the real challenge is starting over and over again without throwing your keyboard out the window.This is clearly not a single player game, but finding matches and people to play with is just a hassle and didn't work for me.+ The humor.+ The graphics.- The whole spellcasting system.- The unbalanced gameplay.- One difficulty setting.- The hidden "BTW" - agenda.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2012
												While teamwork may take a backseat in magicka, it's where the gameplay really shines. Just try to work with your friends, try to get four players with massive area affecting spells to keep from killing one another. With the list of different elements to combine, you've got virtually limitless potential to make your own spells, many weapons throughout the world, and even multiple robes that affect your gameplay statistics. Magicka is a wonderfully simple-yet-complex adventure game that's great fun to play with your pals.7.5/10
