												It's rare to come across a co-op game that involves killing your team just as much as it does killing your enemies. Embracing 8 elements of magic, use your wits and your keyboard to cast powerful spells and brilliant magics. Utilise special combinations of elements to take down your enemies (and your friends). Planning strategies together is just as much of a blast as going against them, in either a campaign of magical destruction, or one of the many challenge rooms available to play. Especially with the amount of DLC available, Magicka is a nearly endless array of fun and hedonism. Truly a clever and hilarious game. Play alone only as a last resort!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2011
												I bought Magicka on sale long after its original release, so my recommendation is based on those two qualifications that differ greatly from major publication reviews. I found the game to be (mostly) bug-free and quite enjoyable, with the only serious issue being multiplayer is absolutely lacking players and those that do play tend to have agonizingly high ping (European and South American players maybe!?). The single player is a good experience and worth the price of entry, yet entirely too short. Note that ALL of the DLC is for multiplayer, which is basically unpopulated. Shame really. One thumb up, two if there were more people playing multiplayer.A month later, and I'm still playing this game almost obsessively. The reason: Challenges. SINGLE PLAYER challenges, because multiplayer is still as crappy as it has ever been - i.e. non-existant. Most players / servers have +300 ping and quit all the time. This game needs drop-in play like Mario needs a jump button, but it doesn't have it. The combination of spells and enemies makes the single-player challenges a worthwhile time-waster, so I keep playing. If only the makers would fix multiplayer, this game would be a 10/10 indie game. Otherwise, even as cheap as it is right now (75% off on Steam), it's still only one thumb up and one way, way down. Single player only for the time being, even during the free-to-play weekend.

Aliás, o jogo todo é bem desenhado.O sistema de magias dele é bem inteligente, e permite várias combinações diferentes, atendendo à todos os estilos de jogos.Valeu cada centavo.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2011
												Ever wanted to be a wizard? Agreed, lets become wizards. But for now let me tell you about this game about wizards. In Magicka you play a wizard. You can play with up to but not including 4 of your friends, who will also be wizards whilst you are a wizard. This is because the game only allows a total of 4 wizards on the screen at any point. This programming restriction is one of the least serious flaws this with game, and that's saying something. Wizard. The game suffers from a lack of control, gratiuitous amounts of bugs, and non-wizard characters. The problem is that Magicka plays like a weak beat-em up. Wizards run around and beat up non-player non-wizard non-characters, eg: wizard. but instead of fast pased action filled wizard baised action baised fast pased wizard wizard combat, we get something less. The fast placed action does not suit well to the 'plan carefully your wizard rainbow beam +1' style of gameplay. In a word, Not my tea of cup. Wizard.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2011
												Ridiculously fun! Granted, you'll spend at least half your time killing your teammates and/or hapless villagers, but that is not a bad thing :D The game controls are fairly simple, but the real beauty of the gameplay lies in the creative combinations of elements, rewarding players who take the time to experiment (preferably on a teammate XP). The story is snarky with lots of geek humor and references to everything from Star Wars to Monty Python and the Holy Grail, and the graphics are enjoyable coming from someone who plays a lot of Minecraft. I have yet to play through the game solo, however, and so am not sure how the gameplay holds up in the single-player mode. All in all, though, an excellent buy, especially if you plan to play with friends (Like me!)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2011
												I bought Magicka on sale long after its original release, so my recommendation is based on those two qualifications that differ greatly from major publication reviews. I found the game to be (mostly) bug-free and quite enjoyable, with the only serious issue being multiplayer is absolutely lacking players and those that do play tend to have agonizingly high ping (European and South American players maybe!?). The single player is a good experience and worth the price of entry, yet entirely too short. Note that ALL of the DLC is for multiplayer, which is basically unpopulated. Shame really. One thumb up, two if there were more people playing multiplayer.A month later, and I'm still playing this game almost obsessively. The reason: Challenges. SINGLE PLAYER challenges, because multiplayer is still as crappy as it has ever been - i.e. non-existant. Most players / servers have +300 ping and quit all the time. This game needs drop-in play like Mario needs a jump button, but it doesn't have it. The combination of spells and enemies makes the single-player challenges a worthwhile time-waster, so I keep playing. If only the makers would fix multiplayer, this game would be a 10/10 indie game. Otherwise, even as cheap as it is right now (75% off on Steam), it's still only one thumb up and one way, way down. Single player only for the time being, even during the free-to-play weekend.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2012
												Some very silly and referential humour makes this game what it is- which is a good thing, because it can be quite frustrating gameplay-wise. Still a little buggy after what I hear was a bugtastic release, the spell combos can be hard to get right, especially in the heat of combat when you're trying not to get punted off a cliff or keep an eye on which debuffs your wizard has, indicated only by graphical effects on his person, and it's far too easy to get stuck in chat mode and realise, after several frantic attempts, that you're just typing AFAFAFACSCSWWWW into the chat bar.Still, like I said, the humour is fantastic, and if you can get the hang of the spell-casting then there's a world of depth awaiting you. I'm enjoying it, albeit not for long sessions!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Majicka is a game about questions, do you want to set this on fire? Do you want to slap a goblin with an enchanted ice sword as large as a baby skyscraper? Do you want to melt your friend's face, revive him, and melt his face again? These are just a small sampling of soulful questions that Majicka will pose to you, but perhaps you are a busy man with no time for trivia. Majicka can also make full-fledged statements. Ensconcing enemies in ice and flinging a rock at their vulnerable frozen forms will make it Wizard Christmas. Wizard Christmas is just like regular Christmas except Wizard Christmas snow is sometimes red and the only suitable present for a wizard is cheese. So if you enjoy seeing your enemies driven before you with weeping and gnashing of teeth do not buy this game.On the other hand if you enjoy helping a friend blow up a golem before using your mighty powers, derived from the deepest depths of Arcana to gently push him off a ledge while cackling madly, then buy this game, and buy a copy for your friend. Then find a new friend once he swears eternal vengeance upon you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2011
												Magicka is a very unique, challenging, hilariously difficult, and immensely rewarding experience. The campaign is nigh impossible to complete solo (took me at least 20 hours, and it's not that long of a campaign), which gives it a ton of replay value. Each level is honestly very short, yet you can somehow waste hours at a time trying to pass a single encounter. You could bring in friends, but then you run the risk of friendly fire, which is always on. There's always that one guy in every party that insists on casting Metor Shower at the worst times, or only uses Lightning magic or fires beams indiscriminately and gets you blown up. But all of this chaos is part of the game's charm. It's satisfying to sit back and take a deep breath after a terrifying boss encounter. Give it a few hours, and "Level complete" will be the two most comforting words you'll ever here.And then there's the humor, which is absolutely spot-on. A little bit Monty Python, a little bit Tenacious D, a little bit silly, and very funny. From the ridiculous voices ("Suprender!!!") to the insistence that Vlad is "Not a vampire", the light tone of the game clashes perfectly with the massacre that occurs about every thirty seconds. One moment, a goblin is taunting you, the next, you've overloaded him with Arcane magic, causing him to explode in a fantastic bloody mess.Basically, this game is perfect... well, minus the bugs, but those are infrequent enough to ignore. Plus, they're usually pretty funny.Overall, 5/5, 10/10, would play again and again and again.

Posted: April 25, 2012
												While teamwork may take a backseat in magicka, it's where the gameplay really shines. Just try to work with your friends, try to get four players with massive area affecting spells to keep from killing one another. With the list of different elements to combine, you've got virtually limitless potential to make your own spells, many weapons throughout the world, and even multiple robes that affect your gameplay statistics. Magicka is a wonderfully simple-yet-complex adventure game that's great fun to play with your pals.7.5/10

												Magicka does really begin to shine when it is played cooperatively. Though SP works, it does not hold a candle to the sheer mayhem and anarchic fun of the multipalyer experience. Even though the campaign is solely linear, the gameplay itself is based on the principle of complete freedom. The experimentation with the different spells and elements is what turns it into a unique sandbox game, which really comes into its own, once friends join the fun. Highly recommended, especially if one is looking for a game to just have a bit of fun with, between more serious affairs like Bioshock or Skyrim ;-)

												Really fun game, especially with friends! But beware with the friendly magick! It has a funny plot and you have in your arsenal almost unlimited magick as you can cast freely your spells, which makes more fun but also very dangerous, even to yourself.It also has a good amount of replayability as you can solve the same maps in various different ways. Has some dlc to complement your experience and only one of your friends need that to start the dlc campaign, so you don't need to hold back in buying one if your friends won't. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Magicka is definitely best served with friends.It's an excellent blend of silly humour and self-satire mixed with genuinely wondrous aesthetics. You need only look at the screenshots above to see how pretty this game is. And thanks to the somewhat unorthodox spell combination system, you can play the game however you want, and be whatever kind of mage you want to be! Magicka knows exactly what kind of game it wants to be and it delivers that without a hiccup. The dialogue is ridiculous but constantly amusing and the storyline is constantly making fun of it's genre- the entire game is like a spoof, and it really is fun when playing with friends.I just wish there was more of it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												MAGICKA......der Name ist Programm.Bei diesem tollen Spiel von Arrowhead Games schlüpft der Spieler in die Rolleeines Zauberers, der entweder mit 3 Freunden oder alleine die Welt vor den bösen Zauberer Grimnir retten muss.Die Spielweise ist denkbar einfach. Der Spieler muss mit verschiedenen Zaubern die Gegner beseitigen. Man hat insgesamt 10 Elemente (zB. Wasser, Feuer,Leben, Akane...) zur Auswahl.Das schöne ist man erlernt im Spiel immer mehr mächtige und sehr nützliche Zauber. Mit denen ist es dann kein Problem die Horden von Gegner zu zerstören :-)Einige Elemente kann man auch selber zusammenfügen und so eigene Zauber erfinden. Und wenn man mal keine Zeit hat zum zaubern, oder einen einfach der Platz fehlt, kann man die Gegner mit seiner Handwaffe erledigen.Das Waffen Arsenal reicht vom normalen Schwert bis hin zur modernen Uzi, welcher der Spieler auch nochmal verzaubern kann und so mehr Schaden anzurichten.Die Grafik ist eine sehr schön auf Comic gemacht. Die Highlights im Spiel sind die vielen kleinen versteckten Anlehnungen an berühmte Filme und Spiele wie Star Wars, Ritter der Kokosnuss, The Legend of Zelda, WOW, oder Matrix.Da es einige ADDons und viele andere Sachen für dieses Spiel gibt wird es nie langweilig.Also los, woraus wartet ihr noch. Kauft euch dieses Spiel und habt Spass.Harry Potter war gestern, jetzt kommt MAGICKASGTDee

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Majicka is a game about questions, do you want to set this on fire? Do you want to slap a goblin with an enchanted ice sword as large as a baby skyscraper? Do you want to melt your friend's face, revive him, and melt his face again? These are just a small sampling of soulful questions that Majicka will pose to you, but perhaps you are a busy man with no time for trivia. Majicka can also make full-fledged statements. Ensconcing enemies in ice and flinging a rock at their vulnerable frozen forms will make it Wizard Christmas. Wizard Christmas is just like regular Christmas except Wizard Christmas snow is sometimes red and the only suitable present for a wizard is cheese. So if you enjoy seeing your enemies driven before you with weeping and gnashing of teeth do not buy this game.On the other hand if you enjoy helping a friend blow up a golem before using your mighty powers, derived from the deepest depths of Arcana to gently push him off a ledge while cackling madly, then buy this game, and buy a copy for your friend. Then find a new friend once he swears eternal vengeance upon you.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												I was debating whether or not to play this game.  Did the usual scouring the internet for reviews and watching trailers to make sure this would be a good game to buy.  Well, it was well worth the research, this game is fun!  The graphics are rich and colorful, the spell combinations your character can do is crazy fun!  I found the tutorial in the beginning of the game to be quite easy to follow and short.  I've played games where the tutorial just goes on and on and on, not this game.  It took a bit to get used to the controls.  For me, I'm used to using the WSAD keys for all movement and now those are used in some of the spell keys, you point, click and hold the mouse button for your character to move in that direction.  I find the NPC's really funny as the speak a form of "simlish" but in a Norse kind of way.  The only thing i'm not too wild about is that it saves only at checkpoints and for someone like me who just wants to get on and play a quick few minutes at times is kind of inconvenient.  But that's only a minor thing for me!   I definitely recommend this game for those who are into magic filled adventures and want wreak havoc on...anything!  Oh and save the world, of course.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2012
												A very witty game that parodies mmany different movies, games, and shows. It also has a unique and well thought out combat structure. From the start of the game you are given access to all 8 elements (water, life, shield, cold, fire, earth, arcane, and lighting) which can be combined for various effects. Each element affects the area differently depending on the form and combination. if you use it in its direct form (some are spray, earth is projectile, and others are beam) it is mainly a attack. if  you use say, earth + shield, on yourself it creates a body armor. If you use the same combination directly it surrounds you with a rock wall. If you use it as an Area of Effect it causes a small earthquake around your character. And if you enchant your melee weapon with it the weapon will also vary the effect.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2012
												For many years I had been getting more and more cynical about games actually getting better rather than more corporately profitable. The lack of creative, enjoyable multiplayer games was quite noticable in comparison to the time of Rune, Greebles, Super Maze Wars and other such titles. And then...Suddenly, Magicka.Magicka is the answer to all this. It has a delicious innovatively smooth multiplayer integration and has a combat system that is, whilst less innovative, so creative and creatively stimulating that its smooth, intricate functionality can only be described as organic.The overall ambience and atmosphere in Magicka is a chirpy, happy, quirky one. Magicka may very well be the result of all that lacking fun and creativity I mentioned being funneled into one single project, to the extent of the quirkiness and continuous references to other media nearly getting on one's nerves. Nearly.Definitely recommended. And *definitely* definitely recommended to play with good friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Ah, Majicka, thou art a cruel ♥♥♥♥♥, to give us such powerful spells that can turn a goblin into a greasy smear, set him ablaze, charbroil him with gouts of boiling steam, or preform crude x-ray procedures with gratuitous amounts of electricity (all whilst we  scream 'unlimited powah!'); and yet you make sure that friendly fire is always on, and we can't turn it off.Then you make the uber powerful spells impossible to aim.But you do care, oh sweet Majicka, for you make death as a slap on the wrist, you soothe our pain, and you lavish us with a powerful ressurection spell easy to cast and use within the first five minutes of gameplay. Oh this brave Macjika world, that has such goblins in it...Okay, enough with the waxing lyrical. Majicka is a game desinged for four players, all of which are extremely squishy wizards with godlike powers, to play online or through Lan. Of course it isn't designed for nothing BUT online play, as Majicka does allow for single player, and in many cases it may be easier by yourself as you can unleash the full fury of your wizardly prowress without worrying about making that red wizard you just met five minutes ago dissapear in a flash of light, a thunderclap, and massive damage.Majicka is, of course, about magic, and magic is surprisingly easy to use, and hard to master. You are given eight elements to mix and match, some of which do cancel each other out, I should mention, and depending on how you use these elements depends on what happens. Cast the Lighting spell by pressing q f a s a to prepeare the elements, then spacebar to use these elements to complete a recipie that allows you to rain down death on anyone stupid enought to anger you, stand in front of you, or stand slightly to the left or right of you (seriously, you can't aim that spell for♥♥♥♥♥♥. Or just press and hold the right mouse button to unleash a beam of death. Or... you could press shift, then right click to send it out in a destructive wave attack. Or hold ctrl and enchant your sword with the elements to create a onetime power melee attack.These are just some ways you can create amazing spells, including armour, landmines (with a variety of interesting attributes including fire, arcane energies, lightning, or healing), create a rocky barrier to shield yourself from attacks, create a force bubble to protect yourself for a long time, encase yourself in stone armour, or ice spikes, or stone armour and ice spikes, create walls of flame, summon a ring of miniature volcanoes to roast everything, crack the earth, make it rain, force magma to spout from the ground, force ice spikes bigger than you to erupt form the ground, raise zombies, create gouts of fire, steam, and/or water, shoot lighting from your hands (unlimited powah!), and more!THe game is full of snide humour, and a silly, half made up language that makes everything funnier. This game is smart enought to know that refrences are not the same as humour, and as such simply makes the refrences clever instead of rubbing your face in it and expecting you to laugh.Of course, it does have a few bugs. Mulitplayer is an ungodly mess, and some enemies seem almost impossible to defeat. Frustration is sure to come if you rely on one spell, and only one spell, and multiplayer cna get frustrating fast when someone lears a new spell called "crash to desktop" (an actual spell) and casts it just to see what it does.But all frustration aside, this is a smart, clever game that is sure to make you laugh, have fun, and want to turn your 'friends' into charcoal and ashes.And rerember... the safe word is: banarner.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2011
												Ridiculously fun! Granted, you'll spend at least half your time killing your teammates and/or hapless villagers, but that is not a bad thing :D The game controls are fairly simple, but the real beauty of the gameplay lies in the creative combinations of elements, rewarding players who take the time to experiment (preferably on a teammate XP). The story is snarky with lots of geek humor and references to everything from Star Wars to Monty Python and the Holy Grail, and the graphics are enjoyable coming from someone who plays a lot of Minecraft. I have yet to play through the game solo, however, and so am not sure how the gameplay holds up in the single-player mode. All in all, though, an excellent buy, especially if you plan to play with friends (Like me!)

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Magicka is definitely best served with friends.It's an excellent blend of silly humour and self-satire mixed with genuinely wondrous aesthetics. You need only look at the screenshots above to see how pretty this game is. And thanks to the somewhat unorthodox spell combination system, you can play the game however you want, and be whatever kind of mage you want to be! Magicka knows exactly what kind of game it wants to be and it delivers that without a hiccup. The dialogue is ridiculous but constantly amusing and the storyline is constantly making fun of it's genre- the entire game is like a spoof, and it really is fun when playing with friends.I just wish there was more of it!

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Ah, Majicka, thou art a cruel ♥♥♥♥♥, to give us such powerful spells that can turn a goblin into a greasy smear, set him ablaze, charbroil him with gouts of boiling steam, or preform crude x-ray procedures with gratuitous amounts of electricity (all whilst we  scream 'unlimited powah!'); and yet you make sure that friendly fire is always on, and we can't turn it off.Then you make the uber powerful spells impossible to aim.But you do care, oh sweet Majicka, for you make death as a slap on the wrist, you soothe our pain, and you lavish us with a powerful ressurection spell easy to cast and use within the first five minutes of gameplay. Oh this brave Macjika world, that has such goblins in it...Okay, enough with the waxing lyrical. Majicka is a game desinged for four players, all of which are extremely squishy wizards with godlike powers, to play online or through Lan. Of course it isn't designed for nothing BUT online play, as Majicka does allow for single player, and in many cases it may be easier by yourself as you can unleash the full fury of your wizardly prowress without worrying about making that red wizard you just met five minutes ago dissapear in a flash of light, a thunderclap, and massive damage.Majicka is, of course, about magic, and magic is surprisingly easy to use, and hard to master. You are given eight elements to mix and match, some of which do cancel each other out, I should mention, and depending on how you use these elements depends on what happens. Cast the Lighting spell by pressing q f a s a to prepeare the elements, then spacebar to use these elements to complete a recipie that allows you to rain down death on anyone stupid enought to anger you, stand in front of you, or stand slightly to the left or right of you (seriously, you can't aim that spell for♥♥♥♥♥♥. Or just press and hold the right mouse button to unleash a beam of death. Or... you could press shift, then right click to send it out in a destructive wave attack. Or hold ctrl and enchant your sword with the elements to create a onetime power melee attack.These are just some ways you can create amazing spells, including armour, landmines (with a variety of interesting attributes including fire, arcane energies, lightning, or healing), create a rocky barrier to shield yourself from attacks, create a force bubble to protect yourself for a long time, encase yourself in stone armour, or ice spikes, or stone armour and ice spikes, create walls of flame, summon a ring of miniature volcanoes to roast everything, crack the earth, make it rain, force magma to spout from the ground, force ice spikes bigger than you to erupt form the ground, raise zombies, create gouts of fire, steam, and/or water, shoot lighting from your hands (unlimited powah!), and more!THe game is full of snide humour, and a silly, half made up language that makes everything funnier. This game is smart enought to know that refrences are not the same as humour, and as such simply makes the refrences clever instead of rubbing your face in it and expecting you to laugh.Of course, it does have a few bugs. Mulitplayer is an ungodly mess, and some enemies seem almost impossible to defeat. Frustration is sure to come if you rely on one spell, and only one spell, and multiplayer cna get frustrating fast when someone lears a new spell called "crash to desktop" (an actual spell) and casts it just to see what it does.But all frustration aside, this is a smart, clever game that is sure to make you laugh, have fun, and want to turn your 'friends' into charcoal and ashes.And rerember... the safe word is: banarner.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2012
												For many years I had been getting more and more cynical about games actually getting better rather than more corporately profitable. The lack of creative, enjoyable multiplayer games was quite noticable in comparison to the time of Rune, Greebles, Super Maze Wars and other such titles. And then...Suddenly, Magicka.Magicka is the answer to all this. It has a delicious innovatively smooth multiplayer integration and has a combat system that is, whilst less innovative, so creative and creatively stimulating that its smooth, intricate functionality can only be described as organic.The overall ambience and atmosphere in Magicka is a chirpy, happy, quirky one. Magicka may very well be the result of all that lacking fun and creativity I mentioned being funneled into one single project, to the extent of the quirkiness and continuous references to other media nearly getting on one's nerves. Nearly.Definitely recommended. And *definitely* definitely recommended to play with good friends.

Der Spieler muss mit verschiedenen Zaubern die Gegner beseitigen. Man hat insgesamt 10 Elemente (zB. Wasser, Feuer,Leben, Akane...) zur Auswahl.Das schöne ist man erlernt im Spiel immer mehr mächtige und sehr nützliche Zauber. Mit denen ist es dann kein Problem die Horden von Gegner zu zerstören :-)Einige Elemente kann man auch selber zusammenfügen und so eigene Zauber erfinden. Und wenn man mal keine Zeit hat zum zaubern, oder einen einfach der Platz fehlt, kann man die Gegner mit seiner Handwaffe erledigen.Das Waffen Arsenal reicht vom normalen Schwert bis hin zur modernen Uzi, welcher der Spieler auch nochmal verzaubern kann und so mehr Schaden anzurichten.Die Grafik ist eine sehr schön auf Comic gemacht. Die Highlights im Spiel sind die vielen kleinen versteckten Anlehnungen an berühmte Filme und Spiele wie Star Wars, Ritter der Kokosnuss, The Legend of Zelda, WOW, oder Matrix.Da es einige ADDons und viele andere Sachen für dieses Spiel gibt wird es nie langweilig.Also los, woraus wartet ihr noch. Kauft euch dieses Spiel und habt Spass.Harry Potter war gestern, jetzt kommt MAGICKASGTDee

content:
Posted: July 27, 2012
												A very witty game that parodies mmany different movies, games, and shows. It also has a unique and well thought out combat structure. From the start of the game you are given access to all 8 elements (water, life, shield, cold, fire, earth, arcane, and lighting) which can be combined for various effects. Each element affects the area differently depending on the form and combination. if you use it in its direct form (some are spray, earth is projectile, and others are beam) it is mainly a attack. if  you use say, earth + shield, on yourself it creates a body armor. If you use the same combination directly it surrounds you with a rock wall. If you use it as an Area of Effect it causes a small earthquake around your character. And if you enchant your melee weapon with it the weapon will also vary the effect.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2012
												Magicka is one of my personal favorite games. I honestly don't even know how I've spent over 200 hours iin this little title, but even now, I could play through again. This game is incredibly innovative and open. There are so many spell combinations, I probably haven't discovered them all yet. It is best played with 4 people but solo offers its own different type of fun.It can be buggy, multiplayer in particular. Also, it can be difficult in some parts, but for me, it never stopped being fun and hilarious. It has a great sense of humor that never fails to make me chuckle even now. The references to popular culture are everywhere.I would highly recommend this game. Its quirky, funny, innovative, and brilliant.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												I was debating whether or not to play this game.  Did the usual scouring the internet for reviews and watching trailers to make sure this would be a good game to buy.  Well, it was well worth the research, this game is fun!  The graphics are rich and colorful, the spell combinations your character can do is crazy fun!  I found the tutorial in the beginning of the game to be quite easy to follow and short.  I've played games where the tutorial just goes on and on and on, not this game.  It took a bit to get used to the controls.  For me, I'm used to using the WSAD keys for all movement and now those are used in some of the spell keys, you point, click and hold the mouse button for your character to move in that direction.  I find the NPC's really funny as the speak a form of "simlish" but in a Norse kind of way.  The only thing i'm not too wild about is that it saves only at checkpoints and for someone like me who just wants to get on and play a quick few minutes at times is kind of inconvenient.  But that's only a minor thing for me!   I definitely recommend this game for those who are into magic filled adventures and want wreak havoc on...anything!  Oh and save the world, of course.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												A mage is walking through a village and sees a woman standing outside of her house with an exclamation mark over her head, and approaches her to talk.  She asks him to deal with rats in her basement.  And in that moment, RPG veterans would groan from all of the times they were given the same mindless tasks, and these aren't even cranium rats!  But of course, there is a twist here.  Everything in this game takes a comedic dump on RPG conventions, lead by a narrator who is totally not a vampire.  What kind of game is this?  It's the kind of game with a Vietnam expansion where you use a M60 on goblins.  Awkwardness of that expansion aside, this is a rather geeky parody of the RPG genre, in the vein of games like Munchkin that find humor in the genre itself.  It's also in Swedish, which gives it an unusual feel.  The game features a unique magic system, in which eight elements are used in combinations that create spells.  Combining some elements create new elements (such as fire and water making steam), while others cancel each other out.  Learning the combinations that create spells is the key to the game, and it becomes vital to learn to enter them quickly.  While the game can be played with a gamepad, a keyboard and mouse are more effective because they allow faster entry of spells.  Up to four players can play in co-op.

												Magicka is a great game to play with other people as well as some solo experiences.The amazing different weapons and different spells makes the game much more enjoyable and adventurous.The game offers the cool spell combinations, there different combinations are a great way to find cool attacks. With the use of different spells, they can be used with the weapons as well. The different characters and DLC's that come with it is a great way to have differen experiences within the game. Although the different DLC's may not be an option for some people the different wizards within the game has a great variety within the game.The campaign mode is great, the different weapons is cool and the use of putting different weapons within the levels it makes the game much more open to look around the levels to maybe find stuff.Also some monsters/enemies have different spells needed to kill them.Magicka is a great game and have different cool things to use, kill with and destroy enemies.Magicka is good game and is worth the buy.9.5/10 is a good game.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2011
												 This game is great! But, like any first game, it has some flaws.1: The gameplay is great, fun, exciting, and fast, but on multiplayer it can be very, very laggy.2: If you have a game setup with friends, it might not be laggy, but without Steam invites and a Private hosting, it can be impossible to group up effectively.3: The extra skins/robes and the level of customizability is flawed in how long it can last (since you die so much), but this is leveled off by the versatility of the spells and that this puts a priority on experimenting with spells.  All in all, this is a great buy for such a little cost. Try it out! You may enjoy it's humor and quick wordplay, but be careful if you don't enjoy linear gaming. Also, around chapters 10+, playing alone is near impossible, so think about that!

content:
Posted: January 31, 2011
												Ive had so much fun on this game its unbelievable, awesome humour (in gameplay and story) with a complex-ish and logical spell creation system makes the coop one of the best ive ever played. One time the 4 of us had to teleport from the top of the tower down to the ground at its base, 3 of us managed the spell perfectly and stood waiting for Yellow (like always). Predictably Yellow faffed the spell and did a face-plap after falling some height.  The magic feels satisfyingly powerful and dangerous (get a spell wrong a few times and you'll see what I mean), and the whole look of the game is perfect (in my opinion). However... this is not a game yet, its a bug that has gameplay in it. While the devs are working to fix all the bugs quickly (on a daily basis), its a shame the game's early days have been marred by bugs that make playing it impossible. Buy it anyway, and coop it up with me, I'll show you my staff...once they fix the coop :D

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												A really fun action-adventure game, either playing solo or (even better) with friends on a versus game or co-op. The adventure story is well elaborated, humorous, with lots of games/movies references, such as star wars, 300, macgyver, tomb raider, diablo, grim fandango, zelda and many more. The characters speak some sort of mixed languages (swedish, english and some gibberish) which makes it even funnier.The magicks (skills) are combinations you can make with the 8 elements given, and even mix these to make other elements. It's possible to create various different magicks as long as the elemental orbs combine. This feature makes the combat style very versatile and unique, besides, in this real-time combat the wizards have infinite mana, use lasers, swords and even guns. And although the wizards have infinite mana, they have other limitations like taking the time to type the combo you want, being slowed by summoning many elemental orbs, the skills duration, and taking care about opposite elements.All in all, it's a very entertaining game, cheap, and completely vampire free."I put on my robe and my wizard hat."10/10

It goes on sale every other week, so that shouldn't be a problem, eh?

												Personally I dont enjoy games with no real end goal and where theres a lot of things to remember, but this game shocked me, since I first got it, I intruduced four of my friends to it and they loved it just as much. Now part of remembering all the combonations at first I was like, "This is going to be a long time until I do that" but I memorized half the spells in as little as no time, because you use them a lot. Also this game is much better with friends than alone, the main story has lots of jokes in it already but when you have 3 other people running around like chickens with their heads cut off trying to cast Lightning Bolt on you or they are trying to cross the beams something always goes horribly wrong and everyone gets a good laugh just to be followed by more fun of the adventure in game, and the DLCs are all fun but my favorite is The Stars Are Left, because it really grasps what H.P. Lovecraft's Call Of Cthulhu would be if it was in Magicka (Although there are some bugs - it just makes it funnier) I recommend this game for anyone who doesnt mind the ocasional paradoxs with time travel or the amount of dead mooses 10/10.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Me: Let's play this Co-Op game I found in my Steam Library!Friend: Alright! Let's Go!5 Minutes Later...[I cast a spell combo that kills friend]Friend: Revive me please.Me: Never.[Eventually dies and has to restart][On respawn, friend kills me]Friend: Karma noob.[Dies and we have to restart once again]After 15 Minutes of this constantly happening, we finally agree to get on with the storyline.Once again I kill my friend by accident then searches up spell combo on internet and then kills me with it.I cried.After this, I find my own spell combo on the internet and then when I get respawned, I kill my friend.Eventually after 30 minutes of us killing each other, we both had probably learnt 10 spell combos each that we used constantly to kill each other.Finally a mutual agreement occurred which we did not kill each other and worked on the campaign.It did not last long.After another 10 minutes of killing each other, we decided to work again on the storyline.He killed my by accident and when I was revived, I killed him.This process continued on for the next few hours until another friend decided to join us. It did not end well for him until he found his own spell combos to kill each other.At the time of writing this review (12.2 hours), my friends and I still have not passed chapter 3.10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Magicka is a fun top-down ARPG that focuses around magic. You can create your own spells by mixing the elements, use pre-built spells that can have some special effects, and play either a short (Took me 7 hours) story mode, a challenge mode with a decent amount of maps (More if you buy DLC), or PVP where you test your skills with magic against other players.The story was comical but not very interesting. In team-based modes you have a friendly fire that really gets in the way due to the top-down perspective. The graphics are a bit outdated but nothing I personally minded. Every character speaks in a fake language like in the Sims, except the narrator between levels, which I found really annoying.The gameplay is fun though, and that is a core element of ARPGs. This game is iconic in its originality but mediocre in most other ways from graphics, to sound effects, to the story, to the lifespan. I still had fun though and would confidently give this a 7/10. Not something you need on your shelf but it's always fun to have a comical coop game available.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												It's like Castle Crashers had a baby with Skyrim, but Skyrim realized he was better off on his own, and left Castle Crashers to raise their weird child hybrid alone. I mean Castle Crashers did the best she could as a single parent living off of Skyrim's alimony, but you can't help but wonder if Magicka needed a strong RPG role model in his life. Now Magicka is the kid that only wants to play Go Fish when he owns a trampoline, like dude, my mom would never get me a trampolone, so when I sleep over we could at least use it for my sake. But all Magicka wants to do is play Go Fish, so you say you have a stomach ache and call your mom to pick you up, but she's friends with Magicka's mom so you can't tell her that you lied about the stomach ache or she'd get mad at you for lying, so you spend the whole next day in bed with a fake stomach ache while the rest of your family goes to Peter Pipers.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												The element combination spell system in magicka together with the multiple robes with their unique features allow a great amount of casting and fighting customization, there are a lot of challanges, especially the additional campaigns e challange maps, both in co-op and pvp, and each one of them is worth playing, the only major letdown is the multiplayer system: making people host the game on their own computer does not require server to sustain, but really makes depend the multiplayer experience on the user's internet connection and provider, so you are required to know some friends or be in a community in order to really enjoy the multiplayer experience.The amount of references and satire in magicka really make it a very enjoyable game, you can try out wave based challanges to test the difficulty you are able endure and if you like high difficulty gameplay the additional campaigns are perfect to test your skills, you can enjoy this game both single player, multiplayer co-op and pvp and hardcore with challanges, there's room for any kind of player there's out there... well you may only be interested if you like the top-down mouse click movement style for combat, anyway it doesn't take more than a minute to get along with the combat system.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Magicka is a fun top-down ARPG that focuses around magic. You can create your own spells by mixing the elements, use pre-built spells that can have some special effects, and play either a short (Took me 7 hours) story mode, a challenge mode with a decent amount of maps (More if you buy DLC), or PVP where you test your skills with magic against other players.The story was comical but not very interesting. In team-based modes you have a friendly fire that really gets in the way due to the top-down perspective. The graphics are a bit outdated but nothing I personally minded. Every character speaks in a fake language like in the Sims, except the narrator between levels, which I found really annoying.The gameplay is fun though, and that is a core element of ARPGs. This game is iconic in its originality but mediocre in most other ways from graphics, to sound effects, to the story, to the lifespan. I still had fun though and would confidently give this a 7/10. Not something you need on your shelf but it's always fun to have a comical coop game available.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Magicka is a game where you get to play as a wizard and combine up to 5 of 8 elements to create some awesome spells allowing for millions of combos. You can also put the spells into your sword to make your sword elemental, pick out of many different characters with there own special ability and resistances and advantages. Pick up weapons from enemies and you can also use the spells in other ways too. There are spell books to pick up giving you a special spell to use that can do things from reviving players and running faster to summoning golems or destroy things at random. This game makes you feel so powerful some things might be a bit overly cheap like rock and sheild but its still loads of fun and as a bonus has online and local multiplayer.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2012
												Magicka is something I don’t think I have ever really understood the appeal for.I played through the game with a bunch of friends; the first thing we noticed was how bad the multiplayer was. It was constantly crashing and we had to reboot and redo certain bits over again. I can’t imagine myself ever playing this game solo in singleplayer, so for the multiplayer to be messing up so badly it was kind of breaking the game for me.From what I remember the storyline was alright, it had it’s amusing moments and parts where I thought “oh, that’s clever. I see what they did there”, so storyline wise it wasn’t too bad. From what I have heard the humour of the game is quite a big selling point, I have had people that have said they absolutely love this game because the humour is just genius. It’s got a lot of references and secrets that are references as well. I thought it was funny to a certain extent, by I personally wouldn’t say it’s “genius”. It’s for a certain audience, I guess?The characters have a really strange obsession for sausages, which I guess is kind of funny, just a tad bit odd I think.It’s still a good game, it was alright. I wouldn’t ever play it again but it wasn’t something I deemed so unplayable that I didn’t finish.The combat mechanics for this game are pretty fun and it’s definitely something you have to get used to. You can cast basic spells and mix the elements  to come up new ones, sort of “combos” which is pretty interesting and gives the game a bit of variety and choice in terms of combat.If you are unsure whether or not to buy this game, I would say that it isn’t bad. But in my opinion it wasn’t that great either.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
 Magicka Magicka is a satirical action-adventure game set in a rich fantasy world based on Norse mythology. The player assumes the role of a wizard from a sacred order tasked with stopping an evil sorcerer who has thrown the world into turmoil, his foul creations besieging the forces of good. Magicka is a brilliant game made on the 25th January 2011 and i have to say...I LOVE THIS GAME. ONE OF THE BEST GAMES IN MY LIBRARY IF NOT, THE BEST.I am not a big fan of RPG games but Magicka has really made me change my mind. This game is superb. Create Spells with your friends .I think Magicka is probably the best mage-game out there. With its amazing sense of satirical humor, Magicka really does bring out out the laughs very often.  The characters voicing and language is the best there is because the way they speak is so humorous, just like the minions in despicable me.Pros:- Fun game that you can play with friends.- Allows you to do spells that the students of hogwarts can't do.- Characters Voicing is very funny.Cons:- Co-op (Multiplayer) needs to be fixed.All in all this is a fabulous game which i would definitely recommend to my friends. 10/10

content:
Posted: August 25, 2012
												Ahhh Magicka. What an amazing, crash-tastic pile of awesome this game is.Once you get over the game crashing on level loads (which is MUCH better than the original release), this game is amazing. Play it will a bunch of friends on adventure, and don't bother going through it on single player (it's the same anyways). There's funny references everywhere in this game.I like to classify this as a "thinking man's Diablo game with hysterical references of all sorts". I classify it as such because as much as you get hoards of creatures to kill, you have to combine elements into spells to kill them, taking into account current weather as well as anything the opponent is casting or using. You cannot just button mash, nor can you cast the same spell and beat this game (though, thunderbolt provides hours of comedic friend-killing fun). Casting lighting on a guy is effective, but much more effective when you get them wet first, or add steam into your spell :)Don't cross the streams!5/5

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Things I liked:It has referential humor for days (Just in the first two levels, it makes fun of Legend of Zelda, Monty Python, Lord of the Rings, and a few others that I'm sure went over my head)Elements system can make for some interesting combos (Arcane/Fire/Lightning laser OP)With friends, it's a stupid, fun gameYou can drop a rock on your head over and over and it'll keep being funnyThings I didn't like:Playing solo, it quickly becomes a game of Ring-Around-The-Rosie when you get more than three dudes at onceReferential humor might not be your thingI'm bad at this game and keep fumbling between self casting, area casting, and normal castingTrying to use Lightning while wet makes you take damage. It might just be because I'm dumb, but it's somewhat hard to see yourself in the middle of a clustercuss being wet, so if you favor lightning you'll quickly wind up frying yourselfOverall: It's dumb, best played with friends, and don't take anything seriously.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I picked this up pretty cheap during the recent sale, and I've got to say I'm really enjoying this so far. Possibly one of the best combat systems i've seen in an RPG. The magick system is fun and encourages a lot of experimentation, which I enjoy. The story is average, but the script is where it really shines, with a ton of pop culture references riddled throughout the script. The levels are also pretty fun. Co-op is fun and engaging and I have yet to try PvP and the Challenges but I'm sure theyll be just as good as the rest of the game. Overall I would give this a solid 9/10, only losing a mark due to the relative shortness of the game (although there is a lot of replay value)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												Magicka is a unique third person adventure RPG. It doesn't have a thick story plot, but it wouldn't need it anyways, as the spells and seemingly endless combinations of spells never fails to wow me.      It's got some great humor and a lot of references that break the fourth wall. Choose to be wizard or templar. Travel the forests and the rest of whatever lays await for you to kill.... or to be killed by whomever. Combine different elements to make magical, yet deadly effects. But be careful-- you can kill yourself. I've found myself humorously mashing the different buttons to see which elements made what. And It's kind of funny to see myself flying across the screen and dying shortly after from combining fire, biohazard ( because that's actually an element, right? ) and some other deadly elements into a huge AoE blast. Magicka is, albeit frustrating, but fun to play.     -     7 / 10

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												ah MAGICKA ... this game is pretty awesome because its nothing like before.This game is really HARD-CORE REAL-TIME BATTLE-ARENA SPELLING MULTIPLAYER / COOP GAME (MMO).Game is combination of real-time strategy game with an RPG stuff also mixed with an "creativity" in spell creation.There is no limitation in spell creation ... only 5 slot system. Spells are created from 8 based elements (water, life, shield, cold, lightning, arcane (death), earth, fire) ... the combination of this 8 elements create a different types of spells.Game is also pretty hard and challenging. And the level of "hardness" is raising like game is more and more in progress. A fanny element is also an online choice of play where you can challenge or coop with your friends in the battles between BOTS (game) or online players (or your friends).This game is really worth any money ... best to get if full with all the DLCs ... and best to buy it in sale. Really great piece of game.+ idea+ graphics+ mechanics+ fun+ hard+ simplicity+ spell combinations+ DLCs+++ addicting- frustrating- graphics- speed- hardGraphics: 8/10Sounds/Music : 7/10Mechanics: 10/10Idea: 10/10Story : 8/10Addicting: 8/10Camera : 6/10 (sometimes was realy frustrating)----------------------Verdict: 10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												If you want to laugh until you cry with your friends get this game, and go ham with your button mashing spell casting spam tastic skills. This game is pretty ridiculous and I mean that in the most positive way possible. The amount of flexibility you get with spell combinations outright beats any game I touched. The challenges are pretty good to and if you want more of magicka there is always DLC though i recommend waiting for sales on those. The multiplayer is what makes it extremely fun with all that team killing and trying not to just survive the enemies but your allies. For what they are asking as far as price this game is quite the deal you will discover things every now and then as you play the game. I haven’t stopped learning new things for quite a long time and I don’t think that will stop soon either. This game has good longevity especially if you have friends who are into it, or just want to go straight to challenges for a game or two every now and then.Recommended for anyone who wants to embrace their childhood love for destruction.

												To start off, the negatives: buggy, tends to crash at times and suffers from rather complex and odd controls.Basically I'm recommending this as a sales product, 5 euros or below is totally alright, yet 10 is a bit too much. It's an old game after all. Multiplayer can be hard to achieve (as said, buggy), altough when succesful it's sidewreckingly fun.However, don't be put off by these whiny ♥♥♥♥♥es who can't get over the controls. Magicka has a great concept, and hilariously fun gameplay when you put some effort into it. Nowadays "gamer" culture is elitist and lazy, so gems like magicka might get dismissed easily.Get familiar with the controls, and learn some element combinations by heart. After that, blow up your enemies with arcane ice laser beams! (or just kill your friends, that's fine as well)

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Magicka has a great concept. You are a mage and you have 8 elements that you can use combined as spells. Like Diablo you run around from a isometric perspective, but you don't really have the looting and rpg elements. The gameplay isn't as fluid as an Diablo. The controls are unresponsive at times. Probably because the game is poorly optimized and buggy. That makes the combat with the spell system hard and frustrating at times. And that too bad because this concept has a lot of potential. Because they created a good looking world with a nice atmosphere. That doesn't take it self too serious and is constantly joking around. But it misses that final polishing to make it a great game. I only recommend it now if you have friends to play it with.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												The game has alot of random features and the storyline might not be the one for the ultra serious gmaer. But this game isn't at all for the super serious gamer. I think that organized gameplay is the most exciting one and I have taken part in a lot of organized events in games like Mount and Blade Warband (with mods of course) and Arma. But this just brings out all the fun with it. The game is developed by Paradox Interactive who are a swedish game studio like D.I.C.E etc. The game combines what we from sweden likes to call swedish which you can notice if you are listening at the npc conersations with you. The game allow you to kill everything in your path and when I say everything I really do mean everything. The gmae has really no borders and is so much fun that I am almost ashamed that I havn't got more time to put out for it. 10/10 Piggys

content:
Posted: February 3, 2011
												If you can get past the control scheme there is a good deal of fun to be had here. The humor is reminiscent of Monty Python and has a lot of niche references few will appreciate. This is an indie title with a good deal of polish on it that will reward those who invest time to learn the spell combo system.  That being said, the difficulty gets to frustrating levels mostly due to a less than intuitive control set up. The steep learning curve ultimately made me stop playing. You can't go wrong for the price though. 7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
												WELCOME TO STUPID.  In this game, the first spell you learn is haste to help you run faster.  The second spell you learn is revive, which works for free because you and your friends will kill eachother and yourselves so often.  That is not hyperbole of any kind.  In this game you play as a wizard who summons the forces of the arcane to your beck and call while still being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed wizard.  You are made of paper and the world is made of scissors.  The game has a splendid sense of humor to help along a bland story, and teamplay is certainly fun.  Everyone is bound to get their own playstyle due to the sheer variety of the spells available, between personal preference and memory, and between this and the MOBA, the devs really do have a whole heap of love for the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Magicka is not a game you'll wanna play after a long day to relax and unwind. It's hard, it's exhausting, it's punishing, it's intense. And it's extremely fun, especially in co-op.This is the deal: You have 8 elements to conjure, 5 slots to conjure them in, multiple ways of casting them and multiple strategies to use them in. Every spell must be cast from scratch every time during even the most chaotic battes, it can damage anyone including you and your "friends" and every optimal strategy you'll come up with may prove completely ineffective just a few fights later. With every new level and every new boss fight, you will feel like this game is trolling you, but you will enjoy it - the absurd humor of the whole thing is a big factor, as well.Definitely recommended - and best played with "friends".

The game has a splendid sense of humor to help along a bland story, and teamplay is certainly fun.  Everyone is bound to get their own playstyle due to the sheer variety of the spells available, between personal preference and memory, and between this and the MOBA, the devs really do have a whole heap of love for the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2011
												If you can get past the control scheme there is a good deal of fun to be had here. The humor is reminiscent of Monty Python and has a lot of niche references few will appreciate. This is an indie title with a good deal of polish on it that will reward those who invest time to learn the spell combo system.  That being said, the difficulty gets to frustrating levels mostly due to a less than intuitive control set up. The steep learning curve ultimately made me stop playing. You can't go wrong for the price though. 7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												So far, this game has been utterly fantastic. I've been wanting to play it for a while, and I finally picked it up during the winter sales for under $5. I have only gotten around to playing a couple of hours, yet I think it's definitely worth the money I spent on it. I love the concept of mixing together elements to create spells; I felt like there were infinite possibilities as to what I could use to vanquish my foes. The art is pretty good, as well as the music. The various internet and meme refrences were somewhat out of place in my opinion, yet so far they've had me laugh numerous times. I haven't gotten around to trying it out, but the multiplayer looks like a lot of fun. The only downside is that from what I've heard it runs like crap on most decent computers, which hasn't really affected me in any way. Overall, I think it's definitely worth picking up, even three years after its release.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												"I advise local just because its one of those games that when your friend kills you, you respond by punching him in the arm."Magicka, a game about being a wizard with other wizards. This game doesn't really shine to well on the adventure or the arena. It shines brightest with lots of friends. This game did something I haven't seen better, and thats Friendly fire. Its that fact and time of fighting a troll, so you go to throw a massive rock at him, then your friend gets in the way and explodes when you release that rock. Its those times where you plant some mines and a friend steps on them and pings himself into space. its those times where you kill eachother because you want to combine the beams and it fails and everyone gets knocked back and dies. This is a game about killing eachother while trying to complete a mission.The next thing is this game is chocked full of references and jokes. Those jokes that give you a cheap laugh. But really the best way to play this game is with friends and i think locally but online is also availible. I advise local just because its one of those games that when your friend kills you, you respond by punching him in the arm.alone :            7.5/10With friends : 8.5/10

content:
Posted: August 24, 2011
												This is a good game that falls short of true greatness due to one fault, at least in single player mode. You can't save, and the auto-save points are too far apart. Moreover, the single-player is difficult, so you die often, which requires you to start a part of the game all over again. Other than that, it is great fun, and I suspect the multiplayer is equally engrossing. Very much worth purchasing especially if you don't mind shutting it down for a while to come back later and retry some of the harder parts.  8/10.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2011
												Magicka is a satirical action-adventure game set in a rich fantasy world based on Norse mythology. The player assumes the role of a wizard from a sacred order tasked with stopping an evil sorcerer who has thrown the world into turmoil, his foul creations besieging the forces of good.Players will be able to combine the elements to cast spells, wreaking havoc and devastation on the minions of darkness. They will also be able to team up with friends and fight their way through the campaign, or test their skills in the magickal arts through other challenging modes.In Magicka, up to four players take on a grand adventure to save their world from certain doom using a fully dynamic spell system. The adventure mode takes the players across three different levels, ranging from the lush forests of mountain valleys to the frozen halls of the Mountain King where wits and creative thinking are the keys to victory.In the unlockable hardcore challenge mode, players fight off waves of enemies..

content:
Posted: October 15, 2013
												I had a ton of fun playing this game, whether it be single player or multiplayer, though playing with friends is alot more fun aswell as the game being balanced more for multiplayer. Figuring out all the different button combinations to cast the various different spells with the hugely flexible and innovative magic system, as well as engaging in melee fights with a wide range of weaponry is challenging, fun and satisfying.The story, while being the run-of-the-mill saving the world adventure type of affair, is still hugely enjoyable due to the humorous dialogue, the many easter eggs that you can find throughout the game, the parodies and all the different film, T.V and videogame references that are mentioned with it's Pratchett-esque wit.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Magicka is not a game you'll wanna play after a long day to relax and unwind. It's hard, it's exhausting, it's punishing, it's intense. And it's extremely fun, especially in co-op.This is the deal: You have 8 elements to conjure, 5 slots to conjure them in, multiple ways of casting them and multiple strategies to use them in. Every spell must be cast from scratch every time during even the most chaotic battes, it can damage anyone including you and your "friends" and every optimal strategy you'll come up with may prove completely ineffective just a few fights later. With every new level and every new boss fight, you will feel like this game is trolling you, but you will enjoy it - the absurd humor of the whole thing is a big factor, as well.Definitely recommended - and best played with "friends".

content:
Posted: February 3, 2011
												If you can get past the control scheme there is a good deal of fun to be had here. The humor is reminiscent of Monty Python and has a lot of niche references few will appreciate. This is an indie title with a good deal of polish on it that will reward those who invest time to learn the spell combo system.  That being said, the difficulty gets to frustrating levels mostly due to a less than intuitive control set up. The steep learning curve ultimately made me stop playing. You can't go wrong for the price though. 7/10

content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
												WELCOME TO STUPID.  In this game, the first spell you learn is haste to help you run faster.  The second spell you learn is revive, which works for free because you and your friends will kill eachother and yourselves so often.  That is not hyperbole of any kind.  In this game you play as a wizard who summons the forces of the arcane to your beck and call while still being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed wizard.  You are made of paper and the world is made of scissors.  The game has a splendid sense of humor to help along a bland story, and teamplay is certainly fun.  Everyone is bound to get their own playstyle due to the sheer variety of the spells available, between personal preference and memory, and between this and the MOBA, the devs really do have a whole heap of love for the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												Funny. Entertaining. Awesome. There are a lot of words to describe Magicka and I can assure you very few are negative, especially after a sea of patches. It takes itself seriously in that it wants you to have an enjoyable experience but its wholly lighthearted and satisfyingly gruesome. The game throws at you a huge array of possible spell combinations and rewards experimentation (although sometimes it just makes you feel stupid) as well as giving you an myriad of cool spells to work with. It is an easy to use control system and generally fun although years of shooters have turned my fingers against this game on many occasions. For an indie game is doesn't get much better than Magicka and I think many would agree. Give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2011
												Simply put: Amazing game, fun, new game mechanics, lots of creativity as well.Magicka is a game where 8 elements can be combined to make different kinds of spells. The combinations change the type, size and area of effect of the spell. You follow a story full of refrences to popular culture and varing enemies. The different enemies will be weaker to different spells, but due to the combination systems, occasionally the casting of spells can become repetative once you find most effective spell and crusing through your foes. This can easily be overcome by trying to think of different ways yourself to blast them down.Lots of fun DLC as well, and most of couse, online and LOCAL multiplayer, bringing a friend adds to the excitement and hilarity.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Magicka proves the statement, that even the strongest basis can prove itself useless at some point. Being an Action-RPG with isometric perspective, Terry Prattchet-esque sense of humour as a selling point and emphasis on cooperative play, that takes place in some fantasy world, surprisingly similiar to what we could see in almost any other fantasy game.  Sounds good? Well, tough ♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Magicka gives a new meaning to the term "frustratingly hard", even when played on easiest difficulty. Mostly because of the control system, that seemingly was made by some mental clinic patient, with severe case of ham-handness.  Some may call this "innovation" but some can also try putting shattered glass and gravel to their bowl of cereal.While the good game usually cannot stand on single-player only, with some exceptions of course, Magicka has also got a nice selection of multiplayer modes. Being a litle interested in deathmatch mode (or whatever kind of gameplay Magicka has to offer instead), i tried playing it in cooperative mode. And it was only slightly less painful than swallowing a bottle of "Jack Daniels" whiskey. What is originaly presented as a coop mode, in the end becomes excruciating cluster-molesting mess that plays as smoothly, as Super Mario on NES, with TV turned upside-down.  Of course, this happens only when you are actually allowed to play, since most of the time network protocol decides to be a total♥♥♥♥♥♥ The main issue with the control system, that it was designed for some alien-like creature. Like any other PC-gamer, i got used to have WASD as movement controls. Frankly, i was unpleasantly surprised, when attempt to move my character with those keys resulted in his/her/it's immidiate and needlessly gory death. Even when i got used to the controls there, i still couldn't fight back properly. And since i've played it in coop mode, i possesed more treat to the other players, than the monsters. Since i've mentioned frustration, that slowly was growing to anger, i cannot leave another deadly sin without mentioning. Greed. Developers of this game really think, that there will be people, willing to spend significant anmount of their disposable income on various robe sets for their protagonists and other DLC's. Needless to say, that majority of DLC's can be called "overpriced", just as Magicka itself "has a couple of pop-culture references". Not that they would cost too much. They just don't worth it. Maybe this game wasn't meant to be serious. I won't question that. But i also won't question that the term "game" means something at least vaguely entertaning to spend time when Magicka utterly fails in this department. If after that someone needs a digital equivalent of my opinion, i'd give it a dead rooster out of 10.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												So far, this game has been utterly fantastic. I've been wanting to play it for a while, and I finally picked it up during the winter sales for under $5. I have only gotten around to playing a couple of hours, yet I think it's definitely worth the money I spent on it. I love the concept of mixing together elements to create spells; I felt like there were infinite possibilities as to what I could use to vanquish my foes. The art is pretty good, as well as the music. The various internet and meme refrences were somewhat out of place in my opinion, yet so far they've had me laugh numerous times. I haven't gotten around to trying it out, but the multiplayer looks like a lot of fun. The only downside is that from what I've heard it runs like crap on most decent computers, which hasn't really affected me in any way. Overall, I think it's definitely worth picking up, even three years after its release.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												"I advise local just because its one of those games that when your friend kills you, you respond by punching him in the arm."Magicka, a game about being a wizard with other wizards. This game doesn't really shine to well on the adventure or the arena. It shines brightest with lots of friends. This game did something I haven't seen better, and thats Friendly fire. Its that fact and time of fighting a troll, so you go to throw a massive rock at him, then your friend gets in the way and explodes when you release that rock. Its those times where you plant some mines and a friend steps on them and pings himself into space. its those times where you kill eachother because you want to combine the beams and it fails and everyone gets knocked back and dies. This is a game about killing eachother while trying to complete a mission.The next thing is this game is chocked full of references and jokes. Those jokes that give you a cheap laugh. But really the best way to play this game is with friends and i think locally but online is also availible. I advise local just because its one of those games that when your friend kills you, you respond by punching him in the arm.alone :            7.5/10With friends : 8.5/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												I know I don't have much time put in but I've played a substantial amount on another friends account. So hear me out. This game.... was made for co op. Seriously. Friends are a blessing, mine especially so please, with tears in my eyes, PLAY THIS WITH YOUR FRIENDS!!!!!!! They will kill you more often than help. It's more fun to kill your friends then the mobs in this game (believe me I know... I was once that guy) and easier, too. So now that that's out of the way, let's get to the review. First of all, pros. The combat is glorious. If you can git gud at tactically mashing buttons in order to get the correct spell that will deal good damage. It's got 8 elements which you will press buttons in order to queue up. certain combinations make different and more devastating spells. There is also the ability to cast Magicks or spells that, instead of firing flame imbued lightning, will cause a thunderstorm or a meteor show and the like. There is also weapon pickups and melee combat. One weapon is an m-84.The game has local coop, even though playing with noob friends is only fun for them (or you if you outcast them) I still see it as an excellent feature that more games should have so it's always a plus in my book. If you have come to a truce and the only time you kill each other is by accident, then you must rely on your friends to cast a Magick in order to respawn you. If you can play tactically, you can make deadly spell combintaions with your friends, to make them more powerful like angling two death beams towards one another will cause them to make an even more powerful beam. Or you can do a combination that instant freezes an enemy your ally can charge up a boulder to shatter the ice encased opponent. The characters and dialogue are comedy gold. Everyone speaks in this rediculous swedish accent and it makes it even better. Story isn't too bad either. It isn't groundbreaking or anything but it's at least entertaining.Music is great and really sets the mood for combat. Has alot of references and secret places where spelltomes are hidden (spelltomes teach you the combinations for new Magicks)So that's all the good stuff. Now for the cons.Cons: ... You idiots actually thought there were cons? LOLMagicka is a great game that I hold very dearly in my heart. 10/10 I got to murder goblins with an M-84 in a game about wizards. As well as a few unfortunate townspersons.

												This is a good game that falls short of true greatness due to one fault, at least in single player mode. You can't save, and the auto-save points are too far apart. Moreover, the single-player is difficult, so you die often, which requires you to start a part of the game all over again. Other than that, it is great fun, and I suspect the multiplayer is equally engrossing. Very much worth purchasing especially if you don't mind shutting it down for a while to come back later and retry some of the harder parts.  8/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Magicka is not a game you'll wanna play after a long day to relax and unwind. It's hard, it's exhausting, it's punishing, it's intense. And it's extremely fun, especially in co-op.This is the deal: You have 8 elements to conjure, 5 slots to conjure them in, multiple ways of casting them and multiple strategies to use them in. Every spell must be cast from scratch every time during even the most chaotic battes, it can damage anyone including you and your "friends" and every optimal strategy you'll come up with may prove completely ineffective just a few fights later. With every new level and every new boss fight, you will feel like this game is trolling you, but you will enjoy it - the absurd humor of the whole thing is a big factor, as well.Definitely recommended - and best played with "friends".

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Most games give you a challenge by limiting you. Magicka tries to challenge you without doing that (though the DLCs seems to have strayed from that philosophy.) The game gives you powerful spells, no mana and no cooldown to limit your spellcasting, and yet despite it being pretty much god mode in any other game, still manages to keep you challenged and engaged the entire way through.The DLC ups the ante but, imo, detracted from the original theme by limiting the magicka available to you. If you simply want chaotic fun, the original story mode is still your best bet.

Only problem is that it can be hard to connect with friends over LAN at times; even if the internet is good, it frequently boots people out, requiring you to completely start over.
