number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
 Keep your friends closer and your enemies closer .. unless you can blast them away... or push them towards the edge.. or into a fire wall or just let them drown .  Magicka is all about having fun and imagination. Use the elements provided and kill your enemies .. and friends  Story Magicka got campaign mode : 12 chapters in which you find items and magicks(special kind of spells) . The story is straightforward - world is in danger and you can save it. NPCs treat you as a fodder and make fun of you until you prove how strong you are with your spells. Also game itself make fun of silent protagonists in general. Devs put a lot of different references in the game so you can go and try to hunt them all . Combat Combat feels a bit like ARPG , prepare your weapon, point at the enemy and kill it .. but without the enemy droping any valuable loot. And your weapon is mainly your spells... or a melee weapon you pick from a corpse.. or a machine gun. Spells  Spells is pretty much the only reason you would play this game.You have 2 kinds of spells.Main one is the combination of 5 elements of your choice and then the secondary is magicks found while playing in which you have to pick set elements to make a different kind of skill that isnt part of the basics.But lets start with the first one.You have 10 elements : Water,Fire,Lighting,Earth,Cold,Shield,Arcane,Life,Ice(combination of water + Cold) , Steam ( Fire + Water). You need to have in mind that some elements are opposite to others and they cant coexist in your spell.Another thing to have in mind: each element got its own form so you have to pick carefuly how to create your spell.And last but not least you have 2 ways to cast the spell, either on yourself or somewhere on the screen.Magicks on the other hand got a set elements and form . Some of them affect only specific ... targets like sprint,revive,teleport while others affect the whole screen like Blizzard or Meteor Shower. Now some of the spells are kinda complicated to learn them fast so you might better off writing down somewhere the combination of key presses so you can cast them faster.Another thing worth noticing is that you can be affected by different elements like you can get wet and when you are wet you cant use lighting and if you try to do so you gonna take dmg. You can be wet, "iced" or set on fire and in order to remove those you need to cast the opposite element on yourself so... have fun !  Co-op While Solo play is fun, co-op is even better ... because of the moments "Sorry, I didnt mean to blast you THAT far ." During co-op there is friendly fire... or more like of insta dead in some cases. While in co-op you can cross beams (ghostbusters anybody?) for stronger effect.. unless you are using opposite elements which lead to someone dying.Teamwork is a must if you want to deal with enemies faster than usual. One thing worth noticing for co-op is that there is no split screen even if you play online Boss Fights The game over a bunch of boss fights which usually requires you to think about what is the opposite element of the boss itself though often several elements will hurting him, there is one that do more damage than the rest. Also have in mind that part of bosses got 1shot skills so .. be careful !!!  Overall Its quite enjoyable game for what is worth and co-op is one of the funniest I played so far. Though solo play is good I suggest you to go for co-op only.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												  Seems like a cool concept for a game, but unfortunately the sole reason why I bought it does not function at all.  A friend and I purchased this together long ago with the intent of playing through the co-op mode, but the game freezes at the same point of the tutorial every time. Skipping by this doesn't seem to help. Others don't seem to be having the same problem, but I'd say if you purchase, do so with the intent to enjoy the singleplayer first. The game is still very buggy and prone to strange problems that might not have a fix.  Aside from that, probably the worst thing about it are the memes and referential humor, which exist throughout the game. If you don't like crap like that and you're intent on picking this up, then prepare to groan.

												This game is great. The graphics are crisp, sleek, and polished. The content is fine and there are countless DLC's to quenche your thirst if the story finally bores you. All in all its great but, every game has its bad points. This game is VERY buggy. The fun outweighs the bugs. Get this game. :)Graphics - 8/10Gameplay - 9/10Content - 9/10

												Innovative gameplay; really like the element combination spell casting system. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												This game is hilarious if you're a geek, fantastic humour.  The early levels/tutorial is great, lots of jokes and some puzzles to solve make it seems like a real action adventure game, but outside of those early levels it seems to devolve into something more like Diablo. Lots of combat, very few puzzles outside of figuring out the best way to take down a particular enemy. One bit early on in the tutorial is very confusing though (shift + left click the rope to exit the room - you'll know the one when you're stuck there). I had to look that up on the interwebs, and apparently I am far from the first to have to do so.It feels like more of a casual game than something for serious gamers though. Unfortunately that's a bit misleading because with the real time combat, and multiple elements to combine in the right order to cast a spell it seems to take a serious gamers reflexes, response times, pattern recognition and general skill to accurately/cleverly counter enemies. Luckily for me none of the combat so far has been challening enough that I haven't succeded (after one or more attempts) just by mashing the buttons widly ;P

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												On magicka you assume the role of a Wizard, from an order full of them, to go and help the king on his fight against evil monsters. Your journey will be full of dangerous creatures and obstacles that you must overcome to save the world.The game has an incredible sense of humor, you will find yourself laughing at the most simple things. The humor ended up getting a little old to me because I ended up expecting a joke to happear every time a cutcene happened or even when i ended up in a conversation.You have 8 different basic magic to use:Fire,Water,Ice,Eletricity,Life,Dead,Earth,ShieldThen you can combine them giving the game a lot of combat variety.Overall a great game and if you have friends to play It with you then you are going to love It.Pros:+Comedy is everywere +Magic Variety+Lots of fun to play with friendsCons:-Bugs..Bugs EVERYWERE D:-Dificulty doesnt scale with more players, most people wont have that many problems doing adventure mode on solo and if you get friends to play with you the game only gets easier.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Magicka is a game with a good concept but poor execution.The game is poorly optimized - it depends on your graphic card, because apparently the game can run choppy even on newer computers.Controls are overcomplicated and feel like not made for fast-paced combat that Magicka is about. The game's mechanics with controls combined can really make you mad.You have 8 button binded to elements usable to create spells; when you are flooded with dozens of enemies there's a high probability you will smash these buttons to spam spells as much as possible. But you really can't since you have to wait for about 1 second to apply an element to spell, which can get really annoying.You press MOUSE3 to use spell on yourself and also use items, like throwing grenade on soldier. Since game doesn't wait for element to be applied when you already pressed a button, just so happens you will often blow up your friends by accident with said grenade.I really didn't like how controls were made, to cast spells you need a total of 13 buttons (if I'm not mistaken) and use them on the fly, when you are trying to deal with a spam of enemies.There's no option to bind your favourite ones to keys, idk why.Your and your teammates' characters are sometimes hard to distinguish when there's a lot of stuff on the screen. I many times had problem to tell if my character is already dead or not, because there's no indication.There's more, but it all leads to frustration.In multiplayer it sometimes lags horribly, sometimes crashes. There's of course times when it works perfectly, too.That said, I can't really recommend Magicka to anyone.

												This game isn't very fun. Especially by yourself. I think it could be a lot of fun with friends, though. The game runs extremely poorly even on beefy machines. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												As a gaming old-timer, I've pretty much seen it all.  Lots of bad, plenty of good, and way too much awful.  Truly unique and fun experiences stick out in my memory like events on a timeline... Pong, Space invaders, Pitfall, Diablo, Ultima (all), ET, Zork, Bard's Tale, King's Quest, Doom, Madden, Zelda, Quake, Starcraft, Sword of the Samurai, Warcraft, Civ, SimCity, Age of Empires, Half-Life, TIE Fighter, Neverwinter Nights, GTA III, Unreal Tournament, Sims, Deus Ex, Morrowind, Oblivion, Skyrim, Grim Fandango, WoW, Fallout, System Shock 2, Bioshock, XCom, Duke Nukem, Pirates!, Knights of the Old Republic, errrr what was I talking about?Magicka is great fun, in any case.  I love the casting system... being able to create a nearly endless combination of spells is very cool and challenging.  In my first session, about an hour in, I dropped a massive magic boulder on my head and died.  I thought that was pretty funny.I picked this up in a bundle... and I feel guilty, because this is worth far more than the 37 cents I paid for it.  At $9.99 it's a definite buy.

Truly unique and fun experiences stick out in my memory like events on a timeline... Pong, Space invaders, Pitfall, Diablo, Ultima (all), ET, Zork, Bard's Tale, King's Quest, Doom, Madden, Zelda, Quake, Starcraft, Sword of the Samurai, Warcraft, Civ, SimCity, Age of Empires, Half-Life, TIE Fighter, Neverwinter Nights, GTA III, Unreal Tournament, Sims, Deus Ex, Morrowind, Oblivion, Skyrim, Grim Fandango, WoW, Fallout, System Shock 2, Bioshock, XCom, Duke Nukem, Pirates!, Knights of the Old Republic, errrr what was I talking about?Magicka is great fun, in any case.  I love the casting system... being able to create a nearly endless combination of spells is very cool and challenging.  In my first session, about an hour in, I dropped a massive magic boulder on my head and died.  I thought that was pretty funny.I picked this up in a bundle... and I feel guilty, because this is worth far more than the 37 cents I paid for it.  At $9.99 it's a definite buy.

number of helpful: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Magicka is a game with a good concept but poor execution.The game is poorly optimized - it depends on your graphic card, because apparently the game can run choppy even on newer computers.Controls are overcomplicated and feel like not made for fast-paced combat that Magicka is about. The game's mechanics with controls combined can really make you mad.You have 8 button binded to elements usable to create spells; when you are flooded with dozens of enemies there's a high probability you will smash these buttons to spam spells as much as possible. But you really can't since you have to wait for about 1 second to apply an element to spell, which can get really annoying.You press MOUSE3 to use spell on yourself and also use items, like throwing grenade on soldier. Since game doesn't wait for element to be applied when you already pressed a button, just so happens you will often blow up your friends by accident with said grenade.I really didn't like how controls were made, to cast spells you need a total of 13 buttons (if I'm not mistaken) and use them on the fly, when you are trying to deal with a spam of enemies.There's no option to bind your favourite ones to keys, idk why.Your and your teammates' characters are sometimes hard to distinguish when there's a lot of stuff on the screen. I many times had problem to tell if my character is already dead or not, because there's no indication.There's more, but it all leads to frustration.In multiplayer it sometimes lags horribly, sometimes crashes. There's of course times when it works perfectly, too.That said, I can't really recommend Magicka to anyone.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												A decent game, if only the lag issues were fixed. The combination of elements is fun, but the game slows down greatly during battle -- so much so that keyboard input is delayed. Nothing quite like murdering yourself with lightning bolts, even though you told the game to cast several seconds before. A great disappointment, considering the potential.Another big issue is the clipping problems. You cannot pass through enemies, which enables them to corner you and beat you to death. Continously getting knocked down, only to heal when you can stand, scant seconds before being knocked down again, becomes very frustrating. If these two issues were fixed, the game would be nearly perfect. The humor isn't for everyone -- some of it is downright juvenile, overly inspired by Reddit's hivemind -- but the gameplay is phenomenal.

number of helpful: 15 of 31 people (48%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Magicka is a cooperative, top-down action game where players use fusions of different elements to cast custom attacks or "Magicks," the game's equivalent of spells. This game is best for cooperative play; I wouldn't buy it for single player. I had very mixed feelings about this game overall and am not sure whether or not to recommend it.Pros:+Really unique and entertaining combat system. There are eight "elements": arcane, heal, water, lightning, cold, fire, rock, and shield. The player buffers any combination of these elements of their choosing (experimentation is part of the game) and casts it as an attack to see what happens. Attacks can be cast in a specific direction or as an AOE attack in all directions. Elements can also be cast on oneself; some examples of this would be using combinations with shield or heal on yourself. In addition to this, there are a series of "Magicks," which are basically a pre-determined order of elements; creating the specific order allows the player to cast that Magick. I really liked this combat system and in my opinion it was the game's saving grace. There is lots of experimentation available and each Magick has its own cool effect.+Above average amount of content for a $10 game. The story mode took my friend and I over 12 hours apparently, although we were probably a little slow. There is a versus mode and survival challenge as well as some support for online play (although I haven't tested it).Cons:-The humor is dumb. It had its funny moments but was also kind of... meh.-There isn't much artistic value to the game. The menu art is not particularly attractive and the silly story leans completely on the humor... see the previous bullet point.-The game is pretty buggy. There is one bug in particular that causes a level to crash in the same spot every time. If you don't know the trick for getting past this bug, it basically means the game is impossible to complete. Even if you Google it and use the trick, it means skipping a battle where you are supposed to unlock one of the best Magicks. The opportunity to learn that Magick is permanently lost. This is not the only annoying bug, but it's definitely the worst one. NOTE: See the end of the review for the trick for getting past this glitch.-The game's menu navigation is a nightmare. Honestly, the menus in this game are just a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to navigate. There aren't any real bugs, it's just bad user-friendliness. The first couple times I played this game the biggest challenge was getting past the startup menu.-The difficulty is not well balanced. One boss will be mega hard, the next will be a walk in the park. Some of the bosses have some "trick" or special combination of elements that makes them super easy, but if you don't find that special trick they are annoyingly hard. One of the game's bosses in particular was nearly impossible for my friend and I, and then out of sheer luck we ended up suddenly winning. We merely got lucky, having picked one particular combo of elements, and suddenly the boss became a one-hit kill.-The game has a the makings of a party game; it's designed so there will be occasional team kills in humorous ways. Some of the enemy attacks are designed to be unfair or OP to compensate for the fact that any player can revive a teammate instantly after their death. This is all fine; if done correctly it leads to a humorous and fun casual experience. But when some of the unbalanced parts of the game (see previous bullet point) come to play, these humorous elements turn from entertaining to tiresome and annoying.All in all, I thought this game created a unique and fun style of gameplay. The way players buffer up elements in an order of their choosing is a lot of fun. But other than that the game really has very little going for it. I was heavily undecided whether or not to recommend it, but overall I think the cons outweigh the pros.For getting past the crash glitch: This glitch happens in a swampy looking area. You reach a rundown old church. When you enter the church, a difficult battle ensues, where the best way to win the battle is to grab the Magick at the edge of the room, which allows you to summon friendly zombies. If you win this battle and exit, the game crashes, and restarting brings you back to the last checkpoint, in front of the church. The way my friend and I got past this bug (after having it crash on us multiple times) is by teleporting (there is a teleport Magick) through a stone wall on the right side of the church. I didn't come up with this, I found it online. This is the equivalent of coming out on the other side after the battle, but it means you can never unlock the Magick hidden in the church.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												I bought this game and turned out to be one of many people who had a bug with super low frame rate.The developers know this bug exists but don't provide sollutions, thank god gamers and people who know more then most people about computers give a lot of tips and for many people there is a fix, but I tried every single last one of them but it didn't help.Offcourse I also tried verifying game cache integrity, reinstalling, all the usual stuff.After that all failed I contacted the developer, they quickly responded that I needed to contact the distributor. Offcourse Steam doesn't do refunds so that's the only party I could contact. At first I got the PR e-mail from the dev. and I got a very polite response within 2 hours. Then I got the support e-mail from PR and e-mailed them. After waiting for many days I got a response if I wanted to send them some info about my computer. It appeared to have a graphics card that has VRAM with a sliiiiiiiiightly lower clock speed while it was much more modern and performed much better. In their eyes this prevented me from being eligable for getting a refund. I explained that how horrible the performance was had to do with something else then just my graphics card, my computer couldn't even run winamp and play an MP3 anymore as it took all 4 gb's of ram and 98% of my processor.(Got a fresh install of windows so everything is still running super efficiently)I also explained to them that this is a common problem that is admitted by the developers. They ignored that part, told me after 10 days of horrible discussing that they don't do refunds and never replied after that. By the way I never said I wanted a refund, I wanted the game to work and if that wern't possible a refund would be fine, but that was never the main goal. But they refused to help me and even when I convinced them my computer wasn't the problem their only response was 'We do not handle refunds directly, you have to turn to the seller to request a refund.' and they never got back to me.So I strongly recommend against this game. I'm sure it's a fun game but we shouldn't support distributors like that.Edit: I got a new pc on which it works... Nah it's not that fun either. Awkard♥♥♥♥♥controls. Lóve the concept, not a fan of the execution.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2012
												Magicka is not a traditional game, and I laud it for its use of new mechanics and great humor in order to provide a fun and unique game experience. However, the game has enough caveats to it that I cannot heartily recommend it. For one thing, if you have a low end computer that just barely meets the minimum requirements to play it, stay away from this game; its optimization is very poor and and it will crash on startup if you try playing it on such a system. Additionally, this is a game that really shines with friends, and will not be that much fun if you play it without at least one friend. The game is also notoriously buggy, especially in multiplayer (I swear at least a third of my gameplay time was just spent trying to connect to my friends after game crashes). There's a good game hiding behind these issues, but there are so many of them and they are so blatant that they prevent this game from being the great game it could have been. As is, it's a good sale buy. P.S., Many people rag on this game for its absurd number of DLC's, but there are only four or so that are actual campaigns; the rest are just skins and challenge maps that are completely skippable.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Magicka has become quite popular over the time for it's unique gameplay and humor. The basic premise is that you assume the role of a wizard and combine spells in order to defeat hordes of monsters and bosses, all in a cooperative manner. The unique spell system where you combine different elements and cast them in different manners sound really intruiging, furthermore you can play with your friends. But is the game any good? Personally I think it's highly overrated, the gameplay seems fun at first but is really frustrating and annoying to me. Combining elements does require a lot of skill but it often feels more like a hassle and it's really painful to pull off the spells. Often you just tend to mess up your spell due to the bad controls. The movement and controls feel really sluggish which take a lot from the fun, it's more frustrating to navigate the map and cast some spells than actual fun. Furthermore if you play with friends it just becomes  a huge uncontrollable mess. Overall the game feels poorly optimized and still suffers from numerous bugs, there has never been a session where I didn't encounter a bug or issues.The campaign is nice and offers a lot of humor but very often it's pretty silly and the game tries to desperately to sell around all the references and internet jokes. It's funny at first but gets annoying really fast. The fuzz around the game is more entertaining the the actual game itself.Get the newest Magicka, I don't recommend this game.

Posted: July 22, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game because the concept is really cool. The system of combining spells is really awesome, and I was excited to try the game out for this reason in particular. However I quickly realized that I could just roll through level after level by spamming the same spell over and over. It wasn't challenging at all. Having a cooldown would help a lot. I'll give the game the benefit of the doubt that it requires you to mix up the spells as you progress further and enemies become tougher, but after 75 minutes of playing I was "defeated" while a cutscene was playing, so I got frustrated and uninstalled. 4 player co-op is a nice plus to the game. It's always cheap, $10 full price and often $2.50 during Steam sales, so it can't hurt to try the game out for yourself. I can't give it a positive review unfortunately.

												It's a really fun concept, but it quickly dies.It's so awesome to have so much magic at your disposal with just the click of a key, and have so many crazy combos to use on those damn goblins. However, I quickly found the two or three combos that worked best, slash actually killed bad guys, and then the game just turned into "how quickly can I mash my combo against all these bad guys" and the fun dropped as if from the face of a cliff.Basically it's a great concept, but it falls short.

												Maybe its just me - but I found this game to be really hard.  The controls are a little odd, but I got stuck on just chapter 3 (of ten?) and decided that due to the difficulty the game is unplayable for me.  I actually thought it was quite fun but I grew tired of playing each fight 10+ times just to win.  The game doesn't have any diffuclty settings so I cannot select "easy."  Normally I find games to be fairly easy, so I wouldn't say its just because I suck.  There is an online mode to play coop - but there aren't enough online players to get anyone to join.Overall I thought the game was fun; but due to the limited graphics, wonky controls, and lack of difficulty settings, I have to vote thumbs down here.

Whisk through to remove any lumps.Cream together butter and cocoa powder until well-combined.Add sugar and milk to cocoa mixture by adding 1 cup of sugar followed by about a tablespoon of milk. Repeat until all sugar and milk have been added.Add vanilla extract and espresso powder and combine well.If frosting appears too dry, add more milk, a tablespoon at a time until it reaches the right consistency. If it appears to wet and does not hold its form, add more confectioner’s sugar, a tablespoon at a time until it reaches the right consistency.Now back to the cakeCAKE INSTRUCTIONS:Preheat oven to 350º F. Prepare two 9-inch cake pans by spraying with baking spray or buttering and lightly flouring.For the cake:Add flour, sugar, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda, salt and espresso powder to a large bowl or the bowl of a stand mixer. Whisk through to combine or, using your paddle attachment, stir through flour mixture until combined well.Add milk, vegetable oil, eggs, and vanilla to flour mixture and mix together on medium speed until well combined. Reduce speed and carefully add boiling water to the cake batter. Beat on high speed for about 1 minute to add air to the batter.Distribute cake batter evenly between the two prepared cake pans. content:
Posted: January 30, 2011
												Compared to other diablo-like action RPG's, Magicka focuses less on the RPG elements (no stat points to distribute, no levels to go up, no skill trees to follow) and is set up as more of an arcade experience. You will find weapons and staves to acquire, but other than that you'll be relying on the game's ultra-flexible magic system, where different elements can be combined as you see fit for different effects, and cast in different forms, while more specific, special,  powerful spells such as summoning or full-screen weather effects can be acquired through the course of play.The game shines the most in the multiplayer experience, where friendly fire is always on and exploding your friends in the most catastrophically unfortunate manner possible is both hilarious and easily reconciled with a simple revive spell.This is the sort of thing you and your friends will play whenever you've got nothing better to do, and just looking for some casual mayhem to pass the time.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Wow is this game garbage!  I am very surprised after all the good press these games got back when they were released.  Buggy as a Bethesda game, unpolished gameplay, slow and clunky, and flat out unfair and 8bit cheesy at times.  Be prepared to have your char get "stuck" in mid cast and not be able to do anything other than die.  When fighting multiple enemies if you get hit with any kind of knock down attack you will never get up again.  You will be hit with the same move over and over until you are dead, then revived right in the same situation.  You will have no chance to move or do anything other than die the same way again.  Many cinema scenes cannot be skipped and you have to sit through them again and again when you die over and over trying to "get" what the designers failed to communicate to you.  Don't buy even at the sale price!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2013
												Wizards have always been in a rut when it comes to games. They're portrayed as miracle workers; quick-witted masters of arcane elements. What wizards are handled as, though, are simple glass cannons -- frail men with a limited attack pool governed by arbitrary numbers and points. The player is forced to forsee several actions and plan ahead, all to achieve the same effectiveness as the burly fighters who charge headfirst into the fray like a bloodthirsty, brain-dead zombie.Magicka is the first game I've played to do wizarding right. Magicka puts you in the role of a rookie wizard, and you progress through the game not by leveling up or watching a magic meter, but through experimenting with combining the eight elements you are given, much like you would expect a real wizard to. What happens when you mix fire and water? Does lightning do more damage than earth? Can you add cold to this spell to make it more effective? You can use all elements infinitely, so the only limit to what you do is what you have yet to try.That's just the casting mechanics. Mix it in with the tongue-in-cheek style of the world of Midgard, based on Scandinavian mythology and driven by pop-culture references. This game has many moments, from hilarious tributes to many fandoms to the excitement of perfecting your favorite spell. It was well worth my time and money.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
Product received for free
												This game is uncompromisingly bad. It has way too many bugs to even be listed, the sad part is that this game does have a novel way to use magic that's fairly fun. However that is all it has.The control scheme is horrible. Next time use the WASD to move or have movement work like it does in any other isometric action RPG. There is a reason Diablo is a top seller still. It's controls are not slow and clunky. You cannot cast spells preemptively requiring you use them as soon as combat starts or your move speed slows to a snails pace (and here I thought you couldn't move slower). The bugs are so damn numerous. You have one that made Steam crash and I was unable to connect to the network short of resetting my net options for TCP/IP connections in my admin page. Another where the game suddenly cannot be interacted with forcing you to control-alt-delete to escape it. Another game breaking bug is that joining or hosting multiplayer may cause the game to randomly crash on it's own merit if not require you restart the game because someone left or you crashed. That's right, if you were in the game and your friend crashed restart it now, because simply rejoining is not possible. Another bug is that it crashed so hard my computer restarted itself. This game is crap. I do not know how this could be considered a release let alone worth any money. This software is hideously broken. The worst part is that no attempt to fix these game breaking bugs and bad design decisions has been made. You must still hold the mouse button down to move and movement is clunky and hard to control in tight spaces and around corners. Bugs keep showing up and rearing their ugly head to make the game suddenly unplayable, and the worst offense is that people keep hoisting this game up as if it's the pinnacle of gaming. This game is bad, broken, and needs to be taken off of Steam until it's actually fixed and playable. Games like this are the reason Steam needs quality control. The kicker? This game was gifted to me and I still feel as if I was ripped off and cheated. It takes a special kind of broken to make a person feel shafted after getting something for free.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
Product received for free
												I wanted to like this game. The spellcasting system should make it a home run almost by default. You can combine up to 5 choices between up to 8 elements. It's not quite 32,768 permutations--order rarely matters, some pairs of elements can't be combined, and repeating an element doesn't usually change much--but it's still a system with a lot of room for creative tactics.Despite that awesome foundation, the mechanics of the game are just too clunky to be enjoyable. The action feels very chaotic and random, and the controls feel unreliable. To give a few examples:If you get knocked off your feet, you can still cast a healing or shielding spell on yourself...sometimes.If you mistype a long combination, you can't cancel it; you have to cast the spell before you can start another.In certain fights, the camera will take a fixed angle that leaves critical parts of the battlefield offscreen or nearly offscreen.I should note that I haven't played this game in multiplayer, and it may be more enjoyable there. Getting thrown off the level for the fifteenth time in a single fight might not be so bad if you have a buddy there to immediately cast Revive on you. As a single player game, though, I really can't recommend this.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Magicka. Dont recommend it, unless you have met certain conditions.First of all: This isnt a normal game made by a normal company. It is a suprise hit, made by eight students of a swedish university, that sold over 200.000 times during the first 17 days.Knowing this, you can imagine the release was BUGGY AS HELL. While most of the critical bugs got fixed as the popularity and playerbase grew, some remain to this day and probably will never be fixed.Due to its nature, Magicka has some flaws, like missing hotjoin. You cannot join online games, that are already past the lobby and running. With the now very shrunken playerbase, public-online gaming with random people is almost impossible.If you want to buy and play this game now, you MUST make sure to have some steam-friends who also play Magicka and these friends REALLY should live close to your location.Best chances are to play with people in your country, crossing one country (Germany -> Spain) may also work, but connecting to games over the Atlantic for example (Europe -> USA) WILL be almost impossible. Insane lag, bugs, constant crashes will be your fate.EVEN when you play with the person next door, there is a chance that the game refuses to work. You may play EVERYTHING with that one friend without any problems, except for this one map, who constantly crashes.You may try a campaign map, it constantly crashes. You try it again four hours later and suddenly it works and you can play with your team. Its really random. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesnt.TL;DR: DO NOT buy this UNLESS you have STEAM-FRIENDS who also play it and live NEAR your location.

Posted: April 26, 2016
Trying to cast spells in the heat of battle is frustrating and feels more like work I played the demo but this wasn't a good representation of what you will encounter later in the game, that is strong and large mobs which need frequent powerfull (read more complex combinations) spells to deal with. Everytime you use a spell you need to type in the combination, mobs will get to you in no time and pressure you to type those combos like a madman. There are no spell slots where you can save spells. I play these types of games for relaxation, but this game does the opposite. I have only played in coop mode btw and would not recommend this for singleplayer. This is not a bad game but definitely not for me due to the casting mechanics and can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Paradox Interactive, the minds behind the popular Mount and Blade series and more grand strategy titles than you could shake Stalin's bushy ‘tache at, have taken a massive step away from their usual romp through history to produce a game that is not only unique and fresh but also offers hilariously explosive fun.  Magicka is Paradox Interactive's latest attempt at taking over yet another genre.  Having succeeded many times in the grand strategy genre and making a huge impact within the RPG genre with Mount and Blade, Paradox Interactive now bring Magicka to the table.Magicka is a cute yet oddly violent and often explodey third-person action adventure wizard-‘em-up.  Quite a mouthful, but it’s a formula that is not only unique but also a whole lot of fun.  Taking place in a fantasy world, Magicka puts you and up to three friends in the mucky boots of four wizards as they set out from the comfort of their grand castle to take on the forces of darkness.  While this might seem all too familiar to the average fantasy fan, it's more Pratchett than Tolkien with the fantasy setting mixed in with vast amounts of witty humor that'll keep you laughing all through its ten-hour campaign.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												FUN PARTThe game definitely has potential: no mana bars or skill trees. You learn new spells by making combos out of life, fire, water, earth, lightning, arcane and shields. For instance, cast water + arcane (for longer distance) on a target. While the target is all wet, cast frost+arcane to freeze it for greater damage. Some untested combos may kill you or throw you off the map so be careful!MANY BUGSBut, man, the bugs are annoying! How about getting stuck in cutscene view when goblins arrive in town? They are hitting on you while you stand in your "shiny robes" unable to do anything! It is even impossible to end the cutscene view or anything. How about the starting area where you have to press Shift to activate your secondary weapon in order to destroy the bar that prevents you from progressing into the dungeon while the game tells you to cast life on yourself? Totally not helpful.Then Magicks. Gimmick spells that you learn, spells of great importance. The game says press Space Bar to cast them but apparently nothing or not much happens. Or a magick can get stuck in locked-and-ready to fire mode and you cannot use it.ITEMSI have no idea how to compare the items that I sometimes find with the items that I have already. No inventory it seems. Too many innovations in this aspect of the game.DLCApparently there are many DLCs for this game and you can see it already in the main menu. Many parts of the main menu are locked because you haven't bought DLC. Not subtle! Frustrating.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												This game sucks.By that I mean that despite the excitement of a flexible spell casting system and destroying of whatever-it-is-this-week-that's-causing trouble, the game is a total pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ It throws you up against enemies that are more than capable of disarming you, make it very easy to open the stupid equipment/TAB dialog while in battle, allows you to be pushed off cliffs, knocked off airships (and respawned off the ship), and insists that you drown in any convenient puddle.I'll admit it's a little fun, but the story is crap and the game is out to kill you by making it impossible to win. Having the goblins be able to climb on your head is a 'feature' that should never have been implemented.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												I get that this game is absolutely hilarious, but the broken, unbalanced physics of combat makes this game almost not worth the inexpensive price it is. The controls are not very intuitive as it is, and being blown to and fro across the screen (if you don’t die on the spot), makes this one of the most frustrating, time wasting short games I've played in recent times. There are literally parts where you have enough time to cast one quick spell, then die no matter what the spell was, because you can’t protect yourself from the multitudes of bad interactions in the game.Buy it for the laughs, and… well... hope you get far enough to get them.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Paradox Interactive, the minds behind the popular Mount and Blade series and more grand strategy titles than you could shake Stalin's bushy ‘tache at, have taken a massive step away from their usual romp through history to produce a game that is not only unique and fresh but also offers hilariously explosive fun.  Magicka is Paradox Interactive's latest attempt at taking over yet another genre.  Having succeeded many times in the grand strategy genre and making a huge impact within the RPG genre with Mount and Blade, Paradox Interactive now bring Magicka to the table.Magicka is a cute yet oddly violent and often explodey third-person action adventure wizard-‘em-up.  Quite a mouthful, but it’s a formula that is not only unique but also a whole lot of fun.  Taking place in a fantasy world, Magicka puts you and up to three friends in the mucky boots of four wizards as they set out from the comfort of their grand castle to take on the forces of darkness.  While this might seem all too familiar to the average fantasy fan, it's more Pratchett than Tolkien with the fantasy setting mixed in with vast amounts of witty humor that'll keep you laughing all through its ten-hour campaign.

Posted: September 3, 2014
												Apparently starting with the wrong robes (including the best looking ones) makes you immune to healing yourself, but the game doesn't tell you that.  Spell system is too finicky- with most spells you can hit it multiple times before casting for a (presumably) stronger spell, but if you do that with shield, it not only won't give you a stronger shield, but it won't even cast.  The game also randomly picks up new weapons without indicating that to you, so you could find you all of a sudden don't have your Master Sword, but have some gun instead.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2012
												Magicka is a 4 player co-op game where players create combos of spell powers to summon dastardly effects. The game is heavy on humor with oodles of references to popular culture and previous medieval fantasy games. However this game's recommendation doesn't come lightly. While I do like Magicka it is a very difficult game, especially as it goes on. Play it wtih 3 others that know what they're doing, and I hope you can stand the bugs. This game is as buggy as they come and it still hasn't been completely fixed.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												tried to get into it, but too hard to. Extremely glitchy, poor map mechanics (the rotating island in chapter 6... I literally cannot walk ON it - checked a walkthrough and the guy has no problem walking on it but when I TRY my character just walks right through the island like it's not there and plummets to his death.) The concept is great and lots of fun - casting spells can take some getting used to but isn't impossible to get the hang of. Combat can get a bit silly sometimes (wall, bombs, wall, bombs....rinse repeat) but the storyline is very well written. Doesn't matter how GOOD the storyline and idea is though, if the game is so glitchy you can't even play it (my laptop crashes everytime it tries to load chapter two, my desktop got me to chapter 6, with the rotating platform that can't be stepped on regardless of its alignment...) so disappointing.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Socially acceptable review: Used a sausage on a stick to kill an army of orcs. 2319041347137/10(Unrelated, but I AM willing to host any adventure/challenge maps if anyone else is actually reading the review.) Actual Review: When it first came out, Magicka was so buggy that spiders poured out of every orifice. Now, today, the community has been killed, gutted, and cooked over the grim reaper's campfire. There are at least a few other people out there, and I hope people buy this game in hopes that Magicka 2 will have an early release date. Now, the game is 99.99% bug free. The last 0.01% are spiders in-game. The developers even released free DLC giving us a few new wizard models, and weapons and such as an apology for the bugginess. (Microsoft joke). This game is funny, unforgiving, and has 2 Legend of Zelda references in it, along with a bunch of other references people like me don't get. Number Review: 8.5 (High-fiving batman while riding a rainbow shark into mordor, smelling like a public toilet)Look up some videos, and if it tickles your fancy, buy it. And if you do get it, and want a co-op partner which won't attempt to murder you at the drop of a hat, message me. Yeah, I hate PVP.

Posted: November 2, 2013
												OMG! I just started playing this and it is NOTHING like the other RPGs! FREAKING AWESOME!  First off, you have a slew capabilities from the begining, which means if you can figure out how to cast a spell, you can cast it!  The game is very open ended in the casting system which does take some practice and coordination.  By being so open ended it makes the gameplay very fun... often from the mistakes you make.  So far the story line is interesting and always humorous.  I think this will be a great game for casual and hardcore gamers alike.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2013
												A game that is only worth playing with friends who enjoy killing each other more than the ever-present enemy. Rife with game-breaking and game-enhancing bugs all the like, it appeals to the ideology that "it isn't a good game without game-breaking glitches."That being said, the impressive and admittedly overbearing breadth of spells available to each hapless mage offers a bold experience for hardcore gamers while also allowing the rest of us filthy casuals to spam one or two of our favorite overpowered spell combinations. The game offers an incredible amount of frustration at times that eventually become so hilarious that you don't even care anymore and come to terms of the frustration being a core feature of the game. I rate Magicka 5 out of 8 vortex portals. Fun for $2, regrettable for $10.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2012
												With one of the wildest concepts from an Indie developer, the game borrows heavily from Diablo elements with Kirby and the Crystal Shards. Sounds interesting, doesn't it?The combat system revolves around 8 different elements that are combined to make spells, each of with can be casted in different ways (from cast upon self, cast towards direction of cursor, to enchanting weapons). The combat system is like no others, and is one of the most unique AND one of the best fun I've had! This game is a MUST Play simply because of this mechanic.But the game itself offers a lot more. There are references to tons of internet phenomena, and even makes fun of itself. Its graphics are amazing and fits the theme very well. And, with utmost respect as a gamer and part game-developer, the difficulty curve and challenge of putting so many different combinations of spells and AI is done AMAZINGLY well. So Kudos to the dev team!There are issues with the game, sure. As I'm typing this, I'm trying to get chapter 10 to NOT crash on me <_<. But the problem is greatly overruled by its awesomeness. So, BUY THIS NOW!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												When they say "Integrated video cards not recommended," that's an understatement.I have 4 GB of RAM, a 2.4 GHz duo core, and Intel Graphics 3000. Intel integrated graphics are pretty bad, but I can usually run League of Legends at playable FPS (on minimum graphics settings). Simple isometric games like this are usually little to no problem to run on minimum graphics settings.This game was a huge problem though. Movement is extremely choppy. The game freezes for a bit when I cast fire. Worst of all, the next event happened: the "Particles" setting was set to off by default. I changed it to "Low" thinking I could run the game ok. After I couldn't, I tried to change it back to off. It wouldn't go lower than "Low." Either it was glitched in the first place to allow Particles to be off, or it glitched and wouldn't change it back.Another glitch: When making my character, I decided to be the Cyber Robe because that sounded cool. At the beginning  of the tutorial, you fall and take damage. They told me to use the heal staff to heal myself. I kept trying and it didn't do anything. I finally deduced that it was because my character was a cyborg and immune to heals. Why would the programmers allow you to pick a character immune to healing, but not adjust the tutorial depending on your class? Lazy tutorial writing, if you ask me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												The tale is more concerned with squeezing in as many Star Wars, Star Trek, 300, Back to the Future, Monty Python and Diablo references than anything else. Any cultured nerd will get a kick out of the character chatter and storybook presentation. Magicka's spell system allows for a wealth of experimentation and gleeful discovery. It's an action role-playing game, but there's no experience is awarded for making kills, there's no leveling, and there's no money to collect. Instead, Magicka focuses on combining magical elements to produce dramatically different effects. Playing Magicka isn't about going through the motions with a control scheme you've used a thousand times before. It requires some reflex training that can reward you with wildly entertaining success on the field of battle.
